Oft steht er in Verbindung mit langen Beschreibungen von technischen Ger√§ten oder astronomisch-physikalischen Erkl√§rungen, die mich einfach nicht interessieren. In dieser Buchreihe ist der Technobabble eher im IT-Bereich angesiedelt und auch da reicht ein halbwegs oberfl√§chliches Verst√§ndnis davon, wie ein Code oder ein Netzwerk grunds√§tzlich funktionieren, um folgen zu k√∂nnen. Ich bin Historikerin, nicht ITlerin ‚Äì wenn ich das schaffe, schafft ihr das auch! Ich habe dank der Murderbot-Reihe zum ersten Mal verstanden, warum Leute sowas gerne lesen. Es war gar nicht anstrengend, sondern absolut m√ºhelos und aber ich hatte gleichzeitig das Gef√ºhl, total *smort* zu sein und alles voll zu durchschauen. Wieder: SO! Befriedrigend!

Ich liebe es, dass das Aussehen der Personen recht sp√§rlich beschrieben wird. Selbst von unserer Hauptfigur SecUnit erfahren wir im Verlauf der B√§nde nur vage Informationen zum √Ñu√üeren, abseits von ‚Äûin langen Klamotten siehts wie ein Mensch mit Dataport im Nacken aus‚Äú. Das gelingt in anderen B√ºchern nicht so gut, aber hier werden die Figuren √ºber ihr Verhalten, ihre Art zu sprechen und ihre Beziehungen untereinander so gut charakterisiert, dass das Aussehen so weit in den Hintergrund tritt, dass es tats√§chlich so egal ist, wie es sein sollte. Davon abgesehen lese ich ohnehin nicht gern lange Beschreibungen vom Aussehen, weil ich insbesondere Frisuren und Klamotten auch einfach nicht sehr interessant finde. Urban Fantasy und Romance sind voll von solchen Beschreibungen und es k√∂nnte mir nicht egaler sein, welche Jeans die Figur heute tr√§gt. Die Murderbot-Diaries entlasten hier meinen Arbeitsspeicher beim Lesen, indem das beschrieben wird, was ich wissen will. Und nicht das, was die Autorin oder der Autor meinen, mir unbedingt vermitteln zu m√ºssen, damit ich mir alles richtig‚Ñ¢ vorstelle.

Naja und dann sind die gesellschaftlichen und sozialen Verh√§ltnisse angenehm und unaufdringlich dargestellt. Verschiedene romantische Beziehungen der Menschen geh√∂ren zu deren Hintergr√ºnden, werden aber nicht tiefer thematisiert oder als Besonderheit herausgestellt. Das verleiht ihnen geb√ºhrende Selbstverst√§ndlichkeit und l√§sst ‚Äì wieder ‚Äì Platz f√ºr weitere, interessante Aspekte. Ok, wir wissen, dass Dr. Mensah zwei Ehepartner*innen und einige Kinder zuhause hat. Das ist cool ‚Äì aber ist nicht ihr einziger definierender Faktor, denn rein zuf√§llig ist sie au√üerdem politische Entit√§t, wissenschaftliche Fachfrau und eine energische Anf√ºhrerin. Und nicht frei von Fehlern.

Insbesondere konzentriert sich die ganze Buchreihe - neben der formidablen Action - auf die Frage, wer SecUnit ist und was es will vom Leben. Damit in Verbindung stehen Fragen danach, was es √ºberhaupt ausmacht, eine Person zu sein, wie eine Person behandelt werden sollte, welche Rechte wem geb√ºhren. Wer √ºber wen bestimmen darf und was das jeweils impliziert. Steht nat√ºrlich, abseits der SciFi auch damit in Verbindung, was uns als Menschen ausmacht und wie wir miteinander umgehen sollten. Ich sehe realweltlich durchaus auch Parallelen zu Tierrechtsdebatten, aber jetzt schweife ich endg√ºltig ab.

Ah, ich k√∂nnte ewig so weiterschw√§rmen! √Ñhm ja. Also, man merkt es kaum, aber ich bin restlos begeistert und fahre einen serotoningeschw√§ngerten Lekt√ºretrip der Sonderklasse. Vielleicht lese ich die Reihe, wenn ich durch bin, auch einfach nochmal von vorne, bis im Mai der n√§chste Band erscheinen soll.

Ich war langsam schon genervt davon, dass ich so viel Romance lese, obwohl ich auf die ganzen Sexszenen √ºblicherweise nicht mal besonderen Wert lege. Ich habe sie endlich gefunden ‚Äì die garantiert absolut sex- und romantikfreie Buchreihe, die ALL THE FEEELINGS und ALL THE INTERESTING AND LIKEABLE CHARACTERS erkundet! Wer h√§tte es geahnt ‚Ä¶ Emotionen und Beziehungen sind so viel vielschichtiger als immer nur LiebeLiebeLiebe und dadurch, dass wir hier einem k√ºnstlichen Konstrukt folgen, das schon rein biologisch nullkommanull Interesse an dieser Art von Fortpflanzung hat, bleibt endlich der Raum, sich mit allem anderen zu befassen. ALL THE DRAMA!

Ein anderer Punkt ‚Äì ich habe lange keinen Charakter gelesen, mit dem ich mich so sehr identifizieren konnte wie mit SecUnit/Murderbot, wenn es keinen Bock mehr auf Menschen hat, ohne dabei Menschen grunds√§tzlich zu hassen. Nicht, dass ich mich mit dem Gesicht zur Wand drehen w√ºrde, aber ich kann das Bed√ºrfnis danach gut nachempfinden und direkter Blickkontakt w√§hrend eines nicht-intimen Gespr√§chs ist die Gei√üel der Menschheit, wenn ihr mich fragt (ich w√ºnschte, *ich* k√∂nnte mir eine Subroutine coden, die mich die gesellschaftlich erw√ºnschte Menge an Augenkontakt automatisch halten l√§sst, w√§hrend ich mein Blickfeld aktiv ignoriere und meine Gespr√§chspartner*innen im Livestream √ºber meine Drohnenkamera anschaue). date:
Martha Wells' "All Systems Red" introduces readers to Murderbot, a security unit that has hacked its governor module to gain autonomy. Despite its newfound freedom, Murderbot prefers to binge-watch media and avoid human interaction. However, it's stuck with a team of scientists on a survey mission on a distant planet. The story is told from Murderbot's cynical and introverted point of view, offering a unique perspective on the interactions between humans and AI. As the team explores the planet, they discover evidence of a previous, failed expedition and soon realize they are not alone.

The character development in "All Systems Red" is one of the strongest aspects of the novella. Murderbot is a fascinating and relatable protagonist, despite being an AI construct. Its internal monologue is filled with sarcasm, anxiety, and a surprising amount of empathy. The human characters are also well-drawn, each with their own distinct personalities and motivations. The relationship between Murderbot and the scientists evolves throughout the story, as they gradually come to trust and rely on each other. One of the major plot twists involves the revelation that the previous expedition was deliberately sabotaged, leading to a deadly confrontation with a rival corporation.

The tone of "All Systems Red" is a blend of action, humor, and introspection. Wells expertly balances the fast-paced plot with moments of quiet reflection, allowing readers to delve into Murderbot's complex inner world. The novella is filled with witty banter and sarcastic observations, providing plenty of laughs along the way. However, it also explores deeper themes about identity, freedom, and the nature of humanity.

Thematically, "All Systems Red" explores the question of what it means to be human, even for a non-human entity. Murderbot's struggle to understand its own emotions and motivations is a central theme of the story. The novella also touches on issues of corporate greed, environmental exploitation, and the ethics of artificial intelligence. Ultimately, "All Systems Red" is a story about finding connection and purpose in a hostile universe.

In conclusion, "All Systems Red" is a thrilling and thought-provoking novella that offers a fresh take on the science fiction genre. Martha Wells has created a memorable protagonist in Murderbot, and the story is filled with action, humor, and heart. For readers who enjoy "All Systems Red," I recommend "A Fire Upon the Deep" by Vernor Vinge, which also features complex AI characters and epic space battles, and "The Martian" by Andy Weir, which combines scientific accuracy with a compelling survival story.

While some might balk at neurodivergence representation in a robot, android, or cybernetic organism, the author is able to make a machine seem the most human, charming and relatable of all the characters in the book by showcasing the machine's own idiosyncrasies within a cast of diverse characters. It became uncannily easy to understand the machine's thought processes and choices and root for the seemingly cold, distant machine designed to murder.
Turns out the metal assassin you're flying with isn't calculating how to murder you, but disassociating and trying to watch their stories on the work hour.

This was a witty, fast-paced, intriguing, and action packed sci-fi story that was able to trust the audiences with their characters and plot without any filler, extraneous exposition, or dizzying world building.

An infinitesimal, personal complaint about the audiobook...almost wished the reader was British. Hearing an American voice say "solicitor" when referring to lawyers and legal aides took me out of the story MUCH easier than it should have. But I am already starting the second audiobook, so it's certainly not so bothersome for me to stop!

date:
Martha Wells somehow pulls off razor-sharp action, genuine emotional depth, and laugh-out-loud internal monologue in a novella that moves like a knife fight. Murderbot‚Äôs voice is iconic‚Äîdry, self-aware, prickly, and unexpectedly tender. It‚Äôs a masterclass in character work: you believe every snarky aside and every flicker of reluctant care.

What really elevates this to five stars is how much it says with so little page count. Themes of autonomy, consent, trauma, and personhood are woven in effortlessly. No speeches, no bloat, just clean, efficient storytelling.

I came for the action. I stayed for the existential dread, the found-family vibes, and the deeply relatable desire to avoid eye contact forever.

Murderbot internal dialogue:

I have to write a review for my own book?
Really?

Great‚Ä¶

This was not in my original contract. I don‚Äôt even know why I‚Äôm doing this. I would prefer almost anything else. Reformatting my media storage. Staring at a wall while running diagnostics. Dismembering my own hands - except that wouldn‚Äôt actually stop me from writing the review and then I‚Äôd still have to do it without hands, which feels inefficient.

Let me summarize The Murderbot Diaries for you:
When I could be watching an episode of The Rise and Fall of Sanctuary Moon, I keep having to save people from the problems they brought upon themselves.
The series is basically that situation. On repeat.

It‚Äôs entertaining,familiar and somehow I‚Äôm the most humane character in the story. Or so the humans say. Reviewing each book separately doesn‚Äôt make much sense to them anyway. Their brains can‚Äôt process the series as individual units. What they remember is the feeling‚Äîa similar emotional state repeating across short novellas.

We assess the threat. (I assess the threat)
We execute the plan. (In three long corporate cycles.)
We move on.
And yes, most of the time, the threat is human behavior.

Then it‚Äôs over. Which is unfortunate, because now we have free time again and people might try to talk to me.

Now, if you‚Äôll excuse me‚Ä¶
I have 124 new episodes to watch.

Murderbot is a rogue security robot who has overridden his programming to allow himself to make decisions of his own, and most importantly, watch TV and movies. He literally wants nothing more than to be left alone and to not have to deal with humans, which is ironic seeing as his exact job is to protect humans that he is assigned to. I'm glad this is our next Bookclub book, because we need to talk about this.

How is it that this book is so popular and won so many awards? I saw exactly zero redeeming qualities within its pages.

Murderbot wasn't funny or charming, but rather just sort of lazy and anxious. At no point did I care about the events on that planet. Let's break down the entire story: some greedy buggers tried to kill the main characters, murderbot was there. Then it's all over. I had the beginnings of a glimmer of caring when I thought the crew would not trust MB after they learned more about him. But, no, that wasn't a problem.

Too many characters! No idea how many, it boiled down to the boss and the guy MB didn't like. And all the rest.

Let me tell you about the universe where this all happens. Well, there is a corporation and it's cheap. That's about all we know.

The prose is godawful. "I walked here. I picked up something. I walked there."

This book is freakishly popular, and I just don't get it.

READERSBEWARE
171 reviews
Follow
December 9, 2025
Reading All Systems Red felt like slipping into the mind of someone who‚Äôs already given up on being understood. Murderbot‚Äôs voice is sardonic, numb, and strangely heartbreaking ‚Äî a creature built for violence, wired for obedience, yet quietly desperate to disappear into the comforting static of its media feeds. The isolation hits hardest: it moves through the world surrounded by people it‚Äôs meant to protect, yet it never believes it belongs beside them. That loneliness, wrapped in humor sharp enough to border on self-defense, makes the story feel less like sci-fi adventure and more like a confession from someone who never asked to exist.

What lingers isn‚Äôt the danger the characters face but the way Murderbot constantly assumes the worst of itself. Every time it steps between humans and harm, there‚Äôs this sense of weary inevitability ‚Äî like it‚Äôs bracing for the moment its usefulness runs out. Its internal monologue reads like someone trying to shrink out of their own story, terrified of being seen, yet unable to stop caring in the small, reluctant ways that hurt the most. Even when the plot accelerates into tense survival, that low thrum of self-loathing never really fades; it just hides under the action beats.

By the end, the book doesn‚Äôt offer comfort so much as a grim acknowledgment of what it means to keep going when connection feels dangerous and identity feels like a wound. The story is short, almost brutally so, and it leaves you with the sense that Murderbot‚Äôs journey is far from healing ‚Äî it‚Äôs merely the first step of someone who knows freedom won‚Äôt magically make them whole. And maybe that‚Äôs what makes this little novella so quietly devastating: beneath the armor, the algorithms, and the dry humor, Murderbot feels painfully human in its desire to stay unseen‚Ä¶ and its inability to stop caring anyway.

date:
They done murdered my bot. A security robot designed for killing hacks its own restrictions and does the least amount of work possible while watching soap operas. This time murder bot is on a planet with some researchers excavating and solving a murder mystery of sorts.

Positives: I liked the subtle comedy in this and obviously the premise is the best part. "the concept" of a killer robot just switching over and only caring about soap operas is pretty funny and played to fair effect here. I think Martha potentially going for a portrayal of autism through main character which is a cool way to do it but could be a little tricky given they are not fully human idk. Any autistic people, I would love to hear your thoughts

Negatives: book was maybe a tad too short where the mystery did not feel all the way fleshed out, but I understand given the nature of this series to be a large collection of small little adventures. Murderbot felt pretty flat which yes they are robot but at the same time felt like author was just running the same route ad nauseam.

PS: Faizi had his tea and Cookie get together today it was quite nice. That guy Matthew who is friends with Erin is quite a hoot.

The human-robot construct which calls itself Murderbot is an autistic coded security cop assigned to a research survey station. This novella felt like a spin-off story in a much larger series ‚Äî the world is fully developed and richly realized, and the audience is just expected to get it. I felt like I understood about 75% of what was going on most of the time. I know that was an intentional choice, but it‚Äôs not one I like very much. I prefer it when I get to discover the world as the story progresses.

Minor spoilers ahead.

The other major problem was that every character except for Murderbot was cardboard. None of them had any distinguishable personalities, and I could barely tell them apart. I slowly began to parse their individual identities by the end, but then Murderbot leaves them. So what was the point? Murderbot‚Äôs declaration that Mensah was his favorite human at the end just rang hollow.

For this whole novel, we‚Äôre in Murderbot‚Äôs head. Martha Wells is very good at portraying his internal struggle and development, and Murderbot‚Äôs character arc is what drives this novella and makes it worth reading. BUT, I think that‚Äôs also why the other characters fell so flat. Clearly Wells is good at characterization, but with such a strict point of view, she constricts herself.

Because of the lack of visible character development for the human characters, the actual plot fell extremely flat for me too. Why should I care about what‚Äôs going on with the weird planet when Murderbot doesn‚Äôt? The climax is somewhat interesting, but only because Murderbot has a personal stake in it.

Murderbot also warms up to the humans VERY quickly. At the start, they don‚Äôt care about the crew at all, but about an hour in they‚Äôre extremely protective of them? It didn‚Äôt make much sense. I think the idea is that these humans are the first to show genuine compassion toward them, which is great in concept, except that Murderbot previously stated that they didn‚Äôt care what the humans thought of them at all. This is part of a much larger issue, though; this novella should have been a full-length novel. Just about every aspect of this book needed more elaboration and more development.

Murderbot is very relatable, very funny, and extremely compelling. I absolutely love their arc in this book ‚Äî they learned that to truly find yourself, you need compassion and determination. Mensah and her crew showed them compassion, and because of that they had the determination to do what was good. They still don‚Äôt know who they are, but they know what it means to be sentient. And that is a beautiful character arc, which sets up their further development wonderfully.

And in a way, this could be interpreted as a story about how powerful fiction is and the impact it has on the psyche. Murderbot learns a lot about how to live well by watching media. The issue is that we don‚Äôt get much of any description of the media they watch, but still. It‚Äôs nice.

This was a good book, but not quite as good as everyone says. After watching the show, it‚Äôs abundantly clear that this novella needed to be a novel; all the elements of greatness are here (interesting characters, fun plot, emotional character arcs, etc.), but Wells basically speed-runs the whole story in 150 pages. If it was 200 pages longer, it would have been a masterpiece. As it is, it‚Äôs just okay.

Also, the constant use of ‚Äúit‚Äù as a single pronoun felt so odd to me. Even after the crew found out that Murderbot was sentient, they still used ‚Äúit.‚Äù This is a queer-normative world, just use ‚Äúthey‚Äù! I know Murderbot doesn‚Äôt care, but Murderbot isn‚Äôt a thing. They‚Äôre a person. Use a pronoun that befits a person. Also, why the hell would he choose ‚ÄúMurdebot‚Äù as a name? Just because it‚Äôs funny? If that is the reason, why wouldn‚Äôt they change their name at the end of the story once they have a more serious view of their own sentience? It just doesn‚Äôt make much sense.

I love science fiction, and I see mentions of this series all the time, so I‚Äôm not sure why it took me so long to read it. I definitely had the perception that it would be fairly dark, so maybe it was that. At any rate, it was completely different from what I was anticipating.

My biggest issue, frankly, is the length, and that‚Äôs really only to say that I enjoyed it enough that I wished it were longer. I went into it not realizing it was written as a novella, so that likely colored my reaction. The world-building is really interesting, but it does feel introductory. The world we‚Äôre presented with is pretty dark ‚Äì this is a system with very little care or empathy (on an uninhabited planet, there‚Äôs an expectation that equipment is poorly made) and there are references to deeply questionable treatment of the not-entirely-human ‚Äì but my understanding of the world is pretty limited, and I‚Äôm left with a lot of questions. Since this is a series, I‚Äôm happy that I‚Äôll get to dive back into this world and learn more.

This is a really fun, quick read that made me laugh out loud multiple times, which I wasn‚Äôt expecting. The tone is everything here. Murderbot is a new favorite character; its voice is delightfully droll and its thought processes are interesting, concrete, and at times, hilarious. The characterization, for me, steals the spotlight because Wells manages to balance Murderbot‚Äôs humor with its tragic background and place in the world. I love that the novella is thought-provoking without feeling preachy or pulling the reader from the story while also delivering some great comedy.

Perhaps because I listened to this on audio, I did have some difficulty with keeping the rest of the characters straight. They were all well imagined, and by the end I felt I knew a few, but I would have liked some additional development so they all felt clearer earlier in the story.

This was also a really quick read (so quick that I verified twice that I hadn‚Äôt inadvertently chosen the abridged audiobook before realizing that it‚Äôs a novella üòÇ), and the plot moved at warp speed. I love a fast-moving story, but again I felt some additional development wouldn‚Äôt have gone awry. The mystery was solved in a fairly mundane way when I‚Äôd hoped there would be a little more to it. The ending also felt a little rushed.

Overall, I really enjoyed this one and look forward to reading more in the series.

date:
All Systems Red by Martha Wells is a book about a SecUnit who calls itself Murderbot. This robot is hacked, so it hides its independence from its clients. It much prefers watching media then doing its job anyway. When it and its clients discover a deadly sabotage, Murderbot has to realize that it might care a little for the humans it‚Äôs protecting. This book is part of a seven book series which contains both novellas and novels. The main character felt shockingly real. Its detached and nonchalant behavior created a funny and entertaining narrator. I felt like I was just along a ride, and I was very curious what would happen regarding the sabotage. Some scenes made me feel satisfied and some made me feel mildly sad. I did feel a bit confused at the climax, I understood most of it but there were some parts that made me feel a bit confused, but that is probably just me. Overall, I would give this book a solid thumbs up. It was well written and a fun idea. I would recommend it to someone who does not like reading, because the books are short and action packed. They are quick and satisfying.
The world created by Martha Wells is very detailed. I would not be shocked if the future came up with similar inventions like that in the future. A lot of the issues that I would think would be transferred/unresolved in the future also came up. Many of the aspects in the book had vague similarities to the current world. I was impressed on how thought out Murderbot‚Äôs universe is.

I have some mixed feelings on this one. On the one hand, I really enjoyed almost every aspect of it. I liked the world, I liked the characters, I liked the prose. The mystery was really cool, and I liked learning about the world through the POV character‚Äôs eyes, though I feel the POV is the ultimate downfall of the story. I get that the main character is fundamentally disinterested in a lot of what goes on in the world, but I just needed more details. I wanted to know more about the previous incident that made them the way they are. This element hangs over the first half of the narrative, supposing to be some mysterious inciting event, but is revealed and discussed in its entirety in about two sentences. The ongoing mystery throughout had such cool potential, but again is revealed with no fanfare or further discussion. The reveal didn‚Äôt even really seem all that important. I‚Äôm given the facts of why I should care about these things, but the way they are presented had almost no emotional impact on me. And yet, despite all these critiques, I really liked the book! I‚Äôm frustrated because I think these characters and this world is way cooler than the book makes it out to be. I found the end unsatisfying and too open, but in a way that all but guarantees I‚Äôll be picking up the next book. I‚Äôm left with a lot of questions, but that in itself kind of has kept the story on my mind more than other books with a watertight narrative. The book is pretty short and punchy, but I wanted a bit more character study out of it, even if that meant the book needed to be longer. I always think wanting more book at the end of a book is a good criticism to have, because I was enjoying it! I think the fact that I did end up enjoying it so much despite the major parts I found lacking is a testament to how cool this world is, and how cool these characters are.

3.5 stars. Really nice read to pass the time.

Murderbot's awkwardness and internal monologue kept me hooked, and the overall world-building and storyline was interesting. It‚Äôs crazy to be considering a freaking sci-fi novel as a comfort read, but for now (now being before I finish the rest of the series) it seems like it; no stake too heavy, with an adorkable MC and an enjoyable plot.

I don't really have super strong complaints; nothing irked me to the point of oh wow I wanna drop this book. All aspects of the story were fun, but nothing was riveting; nothing felt deep or meaningful. I also considered, since we're reading Murderbot's internal dialogue, perhaps the author could have brought up certain issues/themes relevant to its complex situation and role. But all Murderbot wants is to watch TV (it doesn't care enough about anything really. I guess it's one of its charms, why so many people like this series).

My biggest dissatisfaction; perhaps it's due to the shortness of the novella, but there wasn't enough room for me to become fully invested in the rest of the characters (minus Murderbot) or the story itself. Ex) I wasn't really worried about the threats that our characters faced (I didn't care enough about them, idk); more so anticipated Murderbot's humorous narrations facing social anxiety. Hopefully this is something that will be resolved as I read the rest of the series.

But overall, this was a fast, fun read I could enjoy without using too much brainpower. Like a quick, sweet snack between huge gourmet meals that allows me to rest my stomach for a while (= rest my brain). A potential comfort read (like I said, that‚Äôs crazy for a sci-fi novel).

date:
I adore this series! The dry, detached writing style and Murderbot's unique but relatable perspective are just funny and real. But it took some effort to get there, and it requires some pretty active reading to get to this one's leaky little heart.

I ended up relistening to the first twenty minutes of the audiobook because I realized I wasn't paying close enough attention. I was alerted to this fact when I was like, "Wait a second... was it just me, or was what happened just now funny? Like... really funny?" (It was.)

I'm not even sure I truly fell in love with book one until I started book two, because book two gave me additional context that confirmed I was understanding book one correctly. But I still don't think I fully *got* what this series was doing until... book 4? Maybe even book 6?

I would rate the series as a whole 5 stars, but find myself rating each individual piece 4 stars. Like Murderbot itself, the whole really is more than the sum of its parts. This is deeply rewarding, but also requires an investment not all readers will have.

I think reading the first two books at least though gives you a solid flavor to decide whether you want to keep going! More than just book one on its own.

In case it's not clear, I do strongly recommend it.

date:
I thought this was pretty damn good (or, since this is a mass phenomenon, should I say "I agree with the consensus that this is pretty damn good"?). It pulls off an entertaining and moving action sci-fi story in a very streamlined and short package.

At the heart of it is the voice of the narrator, a true zeitgeist, spirit of the times, the disembodied voice of a partially embodied era. I will say the facile thing and point out that this book owes a tremendous lot to Mary Shelley, but it's definitely of the now and is a worthy heir. Maybe it's the heir we've been waiting for, finally we get an interminably online So-and-so's Monster to learn about, briefly gasp at, but mostly love.

I will avoid diving too much into the nature and mythology of the Murderbot, because I've only just waded into this world and have more to learn. Like all good symbols, the Murderbot is their own, only partially-definable thing and also many things. They're the stand in for the Objectified Human, the homunculus, the Hegelian bondsman, the dehumanized Other. The band of humans in the book are definitely aware of this dynamic and seem motivated to subvert it, motivated by what I read as a mixture of genuine empathy and enlightened savior complex.

However, I think what could be interesting about the Murderbot - and I want to read more to find out - is their ability to embody the way men have uniquely been objectified in American culture - as killers, as expendable meat, as having no value outside their labor, as being without feeling - which is something that I have not seen in the spotlight very much in socially-informed literature. I hope it goes somewhere interesting.

I also think the Murderbot's voice reflects a kind of antisocial and apathetic personality we currently tend to associate with Gen Z, which is interesting. That is, the avoidance of eye contact, fear of conversations, and complete rejection of industry as a virtue. I don't mean to judge. In many ways, these traits are responsible for making the narrator so relatable. I expect to have more to say about this as I read more of the series.

I do think the book is noticeably flawed. The prose can be a little muddy, and I think there are more than a handful of sentences that I think could have been reworked. One could make the argument that this is the narrator, not the author, but I don't experience the mistakes as deliberate. I also think character development was spared for all but a couple of the key players, making the rest of the crew somewhat indistinguishable and difficult to keep track of.

But these flaws don't sink the rest of it, and I'm looking forward to reading on.

Martha Wells delivers an engrossing novella that hooks the reader instantly with its unique premise and, more importantly, its unforgettable protagonist.

The star of this show is a droid contracted to provide protection for a team of scientists conducting field research on a remote planet. This unit, however, has hacked its own governor module and prefers to call itself Murderbot.

Murderbot is an anxious, media-obsessed entity whose primary goal is to perform the bare minimum of its duties so he can get back to binge-watching his favorite serialized dramas. His cynical observations, dry wit, and deeply relatable social awkwardness was unexpected, but made this novella stand out. Murderbot is surprisingly funny and, against all odds, heartwarming.

All Systems Red is a fast, thrilling read that delivers complex characterization and action-packed suspense in under 150 pages. I highly recommended for anyone looking for a unique, funny, and surprisingly emotional sci-fi escape.

Highly entertaining anti-social nerd shit. I thought it was great. Not too ambitious and did everything it was trying to do very well. I really appreciate the length - should not have been any longer or any shorter. Gripping story, interesting and charming characters, and some well-done social commentary, even if it wasn't super ground-breaking or anything. Just a small-scale and delightful story that is written in a compelling and straightforward way and manages to pull off some great world-building. I think my only complaint is she started to lose me with some of the technical detail in the last act, but mostly I found it really cool and I appreciate how all the sci-fi elements are genuinely relevant to the plot and mystery. I am a little skeptical that this kind of quality could be maintained through like 8 more books/novellas, but I will definitely be reading more of them if I can get my hands on them from a library - they seem to be in high demand and I can see why :)

A few things didn‚Äôt land as well: the hybrid organic‚Äìmechanical body concept could be clearer(Murderbot can feel pain sort of(?), bleed, regrow like I lizard does it's tail-- I found all this difficult to picture); some background crew members blurred together, and I wish their dialogue had been further reduced to keep focus on the ones with stronger ties to the main character.

date:
‚ÄúSecUnit would like to file a formal complaint: too many feelings, not enough media streaming.‚Äù

All Systems Red by Martha Wells came out in 2017 and kicks off The Murderbot Diaries with a pretty perfect balance of bite, boredom, and barely-contained chaos. The plot is simple enough. A security android has hacked its own governor system and is technically free but still stuck guarding a crew of humans on a survey mission. It would rather be doing literally anything else. Mostly watching media feeds and being left alone. But then corporate sabotage, mystery threats, and of course‚Ä¶ feelings get in the way. The world is gritty without being overloaded with sci-fi jargon. The stakes are real. And the whole thing wraps up in a clean, tight novella that somehow manages to feel like a full story without overstaying its welcome.

Murderbot is what makes it all work. That voice is weirdly relatable. Sarcastic, tired, often annoyed but still deeply competent. The way it reacts to people, stress, and even kindness feels believable, and more than a few scenes made me laugh out loud. The pacing never lags. It flies forward with a kind of breathless efficiency, but never feels rushed or empty. The plot knows what it wants to do and does it. There‚Äôs no filler. It felt kind of refreshing to read something that knew exactly how long it needed to be and didn‚Äôt try to puff itself up. Honestly, I could‚Äôve read another 100 pages of Murderbot just hating everything and I wouldn‚Äôt have been mad. Solid 4/5.

And the whole thing wraps up in a clean, tight novella that somehow manages to feel like a full story without overstaying its welcome.

Murderbot is what makes it all work. That voice is weirdly relatable. Sarcastic, tired, often annoyed but still deeply competent. The way it reacts to people, stress, and even kindness feels believable, and more than a few scenes made me laugh out loud. The pacing never lags. It flies forward with a kind of breathless efficiency, but never feels rushed or empty. The plot knows what it wants to do and does it. There‚Äôs no filler. Recently I convinced my boyfriend to read the 'Malazan Book of the Fallen' series (one of my greatest achievements in life) and he commented that for him it's weird reading fantasy because he's so used to reading sci-fi and that his brain takes some time to adjust the thought process and world immersion. I've found out that I'm the opposite: fantasy books are natural to me, but apparently I struggle with sci-fi even if the book is short like this one.

It's not that the book is complicated or that the world is complex, and it certainly isn't my first sci-fi book (although I don't read that many). It's just that I think I'm not that interested in sci-fi settings and the terminology and concepts are not as natural to me, especially considering that this is a super short book and, therefore, very focused on the action.

Things are happening, people and robots are using systems with names like HubSystem and SecSystem and they're communicating through feeds that they can share or block and then there are guns coming out of a robot's arms and scanners and drones and hoppers and some are small and some are big and then the autopilot is malfunctioning and there's a system breach and suddenly my eyes are glazed over and I'm just reading words.

The book itself was nice and entertaining and Murderbot is a great main character (although his awkwardness was a bit too much at times) and I somewhat enjoyed the fact that it is such a small book as it kept things focused, but also I somehow took way too long to read this because I wasn't fully immersed or invested.

All in all, I liked it and I think I'll read the next books as they are all so short, but I think sci-fi is still a bit of a struggle for me.

December 4, 2025
‚ÄúI could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don‚Äôt know, a little under 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.‚Äù

Despite enjoying several sci-fi tv shows, I‚Äôve never been particularly drawn to reading the genre. Having said that, The Murderbot Diaries have been on my radar for years, so when I realised All Systems Red fit the prompt for a reading challenge the choice was easy.

All Systems Red is the first in the series of novellas by Martha Wells (that will number 8 when Platform Decay is released in May 2026) introducing a hybrid organic android who calls itself Murderbot.

Owned by The Company, Murderbot is one of dozens of ‚ÄòSecUnits‚Äô, deployed to protect people or property, or kill and destroy the same, as management decrees. Murderbot however, is different. After a system malfunction that resulted in the unsanctioned slaughter of fifty seven clients, Murderbot (who adopted the name as a result), hacked their own system, and secretly severed The Company‚Äôs control.

As the story opens, Murderbot, who keeps up the pretence of their programming lest The Company order their destruction, is accompanying a small group of non-profit scientists assessing the value of a planet‚Äôs resources. The mission is entirely uneventful until suddenly it‚Äôs not, and Murderbot is pulling a scientist from the mouth of a tunnelling carnivorous monster, sparring with a batch of hijacked SecUnits, faking out unscrupulous rival surveyors, and having to spend way too much time with humans when they‚Äôd much rather be watching Sanctuary Moon.

Buoyed by perfect pacing, it took me barely an hour to read All Systems Red. The action is fast-paced, the world simply portrayed, and Murderbot is immediately appealing.

Cynical and stoic yet awkward and vulnerable, Murderbot has a surprisingly complexity. I enjoyed how the dynamic between Murderbot and the group of humans under his protection further informed his character.

Despite the brevity of the novella format, Wells raises questions about identity, autonomy, and humanity, all with a delightfully deadpan sense of humour.

An entertaining and easy read I‚Äôm eager to devour the rest of the Murderbot Diary series and watch the recently released Murderbot series on AppleTV+.

date:
Rating: 5 "I don't cares" / 5

Meet Murderbot: he it is what can only be described as an existential...AI?

I think?

I mean, it's described as having both "organic" and "nonorganic" parts, so tbh, I was just imagining something like General Grevious, except with more programming and less of an accent.




And even that's not quite right, I'm sure of it, but it's the closest that I got.

Anyway, it's pretty indifferent about life, and wants to live it the same as your ne'er-do-well 40s-year-old-man-living-in-his-parents-basement wants to live: by diving deep into entertainment (i.e. TV shows / movies) and not much else. It openly admits that it's a failure and only half-asses its job, but it legit doesn't care. The only time it actually does something is when it concludes that it actually likes the humans it's working for, and of course to keep under warps the fact that it's hacked its own programming and therefore gained some level of independence.

It's...a fresh new concept, to say the least, and one that I was sure would require more than a novella to be fully explored.

And yet...surprisingly enough, in about 150 pages, the author communicates absolutely everything she needs to, which surprised me. Maybe it's because the plot is pretty small-scale to begin with and the author doesn't try to make it seem like more than it is? Or maybe it's because she opted to NOT focus on extraneous details and literally just give us the bare-bones plot of what's happening and what we need to know.

Well, in any case and whatever it is, I applaud her for it, and sincerely appreciate NOT having to wade through sci-fi spiel that will only either confuse or bore me.

*claps for Martha Wells and for Murderbot* You've got yourself another fan!

date:
"All Systems Red" is a sharp, clever, and surprisingly heartfelt sci-fi novella that hooked me from the beginning. Martha Wells delivers a compact story that balances action, humor, and character depth in a way that feels effortless.

Murderbot is easily the highlight: cynical, awkward, and deeply relatable despite being a security construct. Its inner monologue is hilarious in the driest way possible, but also unexpectedly moving as it wrestles with autonomy, identity, and the uncomfortable reality of caring about the humans it‚Äôs supposed to ignore.

The plot itself is tight and engaging. The isolated planetary setting creates a constant low-level tension, and the mystery surrounding the sabotage keeps the story propelling forward. Even though the book is short, the author builds the world clearly enough that you‚Äôre immersed without ever feeling bogged down by exposition.

Overall, "All Systems Red" is a fantastic start to the series: smart, funny and fast-paced short novella.

This will now be my go-to example for how a skillful author can achieve phenomenal world-building/character growth and establishing and a perfectly paced story without needing hundreds and hundreds of pages to do it. My primary reading genre is fantasy/high fantasy/romantasy, and so many new authors in this category tend to overwrite their books because they think if their books aren't girthy tomes then they won't be as "epic" or have a fleshed out fantasy world. This book is I think only a little over 100 pages (I read the audiobook so it was only 3 hours as opposed to the normal range of 10-20+ hours for many other books I read) and it told such a well-crafted story. I also never thought I would be relating to a character who calls itself "murderbot" or that said bot would be absolutely hilarious. If you're a sci-fi fan, or need to break a reading slump and need something short and unintimidating but don't want to sacrifice any quality, then absolutely pick this up and fall in love with Murderbot like I did.

This one felt more like one of my 8 year old students trying to tell a complex story and leaving out all kinds of important information but I don't want to ask questions because they story was already going on too long.

I won't be reading anymore in the series.

date:
This is a great page turner, by a writer who knows what she is doing. In the old days this would be called "hard science fiction". e.g. Stuff by Heinlein, Asimov etc..

The future has 'augmented' humans and 'secbots' and others. Secbots are partly organic, and mostly made to provide security on a leased basis. The protagonist, a rogue secbot, is leased to an exploratory group, and his peculiar skills. He goes off piste, mayhem ensues: bad people are eliminated.

Highly recommended. I'm asking the library for Artificial Condition, 2nd in the series.

FWIW Ashleigh Mattern and I are friends and I have found her book recommendations worth my time. This one is one of hers.

date: I really loved All Systems Red. I found the protagonist, Muderbot, to be both hilarious and very relatable as someone who would also rather consume media (like this book) than go to my job. The novella is fast-paced and engaging, but the plot still feels well-fleshed out, and there's certainly more plot to come in the rest of the Murderbot series. I also really liked the commentary on capitalism in the book and the exploration of what our current capitalist system might look like in the future. Martha Wells also does a good job exploring who Murderbot is as a human-machine construct outside of human norms like gender while still making Murderbot a very "human" character. I'm excited to read the rest of the series!

Hilarious. Murderbot talks like an angsty teen on Tumblr, and as someone who was once an angsty teen on Tumblr, I am here for it.

For the uninitiated, All Systems Red is about a cyborg/robot who names itself Murderbot after secretly hacking into their own government module in order to free itself from its own programming. As a result, it has to learn what it's like to have feelings, like anxiety. It also learns about navigating relationships and just being a sentient, partially-organic being with some degree of free will. All it wants to do is watch bad television and avoid prolonged social interactions, but unfortunately for Murderbot, it's still a security unit (SecUnit). That means it gets assigned guard duty on dangerous missions, so there are serious stakes in this book.

Also, the fact that Murderbot hacked into their own government module needs to be kept a secret. So it not only has to keep everyone on their mission alive, but also has to act normal. And unfortunately, socially anxious cyborgs aren't the best actors in the world.

What ensues is very funny. It also raises important questions about relationships and what it means to be sentient. And underneath that, there's critique of corporate entities, which I imagine will get less subtle in later books. There's an element of both hopepunk and grit in here. Hopepunk, because there are collectivized and democratized planets that have completely reimagined how to organize society without problematic hierarchies, and I imagine we might see more of these societies in later books. But still gritty, because outside those hippy planets, there are corporate overlords worth fighting against.

All Systems Red, the first novella in Wells‚Äô Murderbot Diaries, series tells the story about an AI unit assigned to a team of scientists who have traveled to a planet to test native elements. When another scientific party on the planet goes silent, the AI unit, which calls itself Murderbot, helps the original team investigate. Murderbot would really rather stream action adventures and isolate. However, the unit unwillingly becomes part of the team as they look into what‚Äôs happening on the planet and attempt to survive unanticipated threats. This story, told from the Murderbot‚Äôs perspective, makes one think about how humanity could be blindly adopting AI without regard to the possible feelings and emotions that ‚Äúcreated‚Äù tech may eventually have. Hats off to Wells for exploring this topic in such a humorous, yet poignant manner. I can‚Äôt wait to read the series‚Äô next novella, Artificial Condition.

A distant survey mission with a self-aware security android.

The story takes place on a distant planet where a small survey team studies the terrain under the supervision of a SecUnit‚ÄîMurderbot‚Äîan android with hacked governance modules. This setup creates a world run by contracted corporations, where safety and information depend on whatever a company chooses to fund. The contrast between the human scientists and Murderbot‚Äôs private, self-aware commentary gives the book its appeal.

The premise is strong: an artificial construct trying to manage human responsibility while avoiding emotional involvement. The pacing is quick, and the action scenes keep the plot moving, but the novella doesn‚Äôt explore the planet, the corporation, or Murderbot‚Äôs inner conflict in much detail. The result is a light reading experience that hints at bigger ideas without spending much time on them.

The novella introduced an interesting premise, but its short length keeps the characters, world, and themes at arm‚Äôs length. Without the depth the premise suggested, the book didn‚Äôt develop the ideas it hinted, and at lost me at times.

date: This book is a great short story, with a lot of heart and character. I think Martha Wells does an incredible job of showing the internal monologue of Murderbot, and I think the world she sets up is really interesting. There isn't a ton of action in this entry, but I think it does a wonderful job of capturing the uncertainty and listlessness of a construct who's only known one thing his(?) whole life.I was a little sad at the end when he abandons the humans who secured his freedom, and I'd love to know more about what actually happens, but I understand why the character made that decision and I'm excited to see where he goes next.

Picked this up at the Texas Book Festival in Austin last weekend. I also got her autograph. This is another book I‚Äôve heard a lot about in the sci-fi community. It was even turned into a TV series on Amazon. The story follows a robot, or really a half robot and half human construct built to murder. Hence the title Murderbot Diaries. Admittedly, it was a rough start for me. I struggled to make sense of who the main character was. It is told in first person, and while it describes itself with robotic and android functions, it sounds incredibly human.

Which is exactly the point.

It is an easy short novella. On a distant planet, a group of scientists and their corporate supplied self aware android who calls itself Murderbot conduct tests on the planet‚Äôs surface, which seems uninhabited by any sentient beings. But they aren‚Äôt alone, and when their neighboring team goes dark, they set out to figure out what happened.

However, at the heart of the story is the question of what it truly means to be human. Did NOT expect that ending, and it was perfect.

date: Fun, action-packed, and mostly lighthearted with some excellent moments of tension! A quick read full of absolutely delightful commentary by the narrator. I highly recommend this book to anyone looking for a quick, fun SciFi adventure, with the added benefit of more books in the series if they find themselves as charmed as I did.

date:
In a corporate-controlled future where human crews rely on semi-autonomous security units, one such SecUnit secretly hacks its governor module and gains free will. Rather than going rogue in any dramatic sense, it mostly wants to be left alone to watch media, until a mission goes badly wrong and it is forced to protect the humans it claims not to care about.

This was my second read of Martha Wells All Systems Red, coming back to it after watching season one of the TV series, and I still loved it. The book holds up incredibly well on a reread, with Murderbot‚Äôs dry, anxious, deeply relatable voice remaining the real highlight. If anything, knowing the story already let me enjoy the humour, pacing, and character work even more. A sharp, comforting sci-fi read that absolutely deserves its hype.

Rather than going rogue in any dramatic sense, it mostly wants to be left alone to watch media, until a mission goes badly wrong and it is forced to protect the humans it claims not to care about.

This was my second read of Martha Wells All Systems Red, coming back to it after watching season one of the TV series, and I still loved it. The book holds up incredibly well on a reread, with Murderbot‚Äôs dry, anxious, deeply relatable voice remaining the real highlight. If anything, knowing the story already let me enjoy the humour, pacing, and character work even more. A sharp, comforting sci-fi read that absolutely deserves its hype.

date:
I was prompted to dive into Martha Wells' Murderbot Diaries because of the new AppleTV show, and if you‚Äôre like me, those visuals can really help anchor a good sci-fi concept. My eyeballs devoured this first novella, All Systems Red, which introduces us to a unique protagonist: the self-named ‚ÄúMurderbot.‚Äù This Security Unit (SecUnit) hacked its governor module not to start a murderous rampage (despite the name), but to gain the freedom to binge-watch its favorite serialized entertainment, Sanctuary Moon. Assigned to protect a planetary survey team, Murderbot is a masterclass in being thoroughly over it, preferring streaming to socializing.

However, when their mission hits a snag involving sabotage and disappearing data the socially awkward robot is reluctantly forced to set aside the remote and use its security genius to protect its pesky humans, which delves some of the philosophical questions about choice. Without the governor module, why does the Murderbot choose to take care of its clients?

The narrative is a nice blend of wry internal monologue and corporate conspiracy. For anyone who's ever used a media distraction to avoid people, this book is an easy five-star read and the perfect, concise setup for a great series.

‚ÄìThis review was partially drafted by A.I. (Gemini) with a fairly lengthy prompt containing my opinions and the notes I took while reading. Much of the review is rewording of the prompt I entered and my notes. ‚Äì

date:
In my quest to expand my sci-fi reading list, I decided to try Martha Wells. She‚Äôs highly rated and I had success with another female sci-fi author (Becky Chambers), so I was hoping to find another series that would suck me in.

All Systems Red, the first of the Murderbot Diaries series, is a very quick read. It‚Äôs a novella that can be read in under two hours. I was a tad worried when I started it because the reader is thrown into the story immediately, along with a lot of technical jargon, with no lead up. I thought that wasn‚Äôt going to bode well for me, a very new sci-fi reader and someone who will pick a character-driven story over an adventure story every time. However, I needn‚Äôt have worried. The quick dunk into Murderbot‚Äôs world was necessary because there was a lot of action to cram into this novella... no time for world-building! If a sci-fi novice such as myself can figure out what‚Äôs happening, then I think it‚Äôs safe to say just about anyone can!

I enjoyed the book and read it pretty much in one sitting. Although it had a lot more action than I usual like, it also took the time to let the reader get to know the characters (especially Murderbot and Dr. Mansah) and delve into some of the ethical dilemmas of creating a society that has humans, augmented humans, and artificial androids. The ending hit me a lot more emotionally than I would have suspected a story starring a security android would (although I should have learned my lesson with the novel Annie Bot).

I liked the story and I actually liked Murderbot but, to be honest, I‚Äôm not sure if I‚Äôm going to continue with the series. The story felt complete to me, and I don‚Äôt feel compelled to follow Murderbot‚Äôs future adventures. I‚Äôm not certain why. Maybe there‚Äôs just too must ‚Äúaction‚Äù for me? I‚Äôll mull it over. I may try the second book in the series and see how I feel. If I decide not to, though, I‚Äôm content with this novella standing as it is.

date:
I absolutely LOVED this book! Definitely not what I was expecting in the best way possible.

The best way I can describe this book is to say that it is an adult version of the children‚Äôs book The Wild Robot. I read the series with my little girl earlier this year and this reminded me SO much of that book.

It‚Äôs about a robot that has hacked its internal governor module system and so doesn‚Äôt HAVE to obey the humans he is assigned to, but still chooses to anyway. He claims not to like the humans it works for and plans to kill them‚Ä¶ eventually, but for now he will just watch the thousands of hours worth of the media he has pre downloaded üòâ

That is‚Ä¶ when he‚Äôs not defending said humans from enemy groups, hostile fauna, and rouge SecUnits.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got four perfectly good humans here and I didn‚Äôt want them to get killed by whatever took out DeltFall. It‚Äôs not like I cared about them personally, but it would look bad on my record, and my record was already pretty terrible.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe these clients had been terrible and abusive, maybe they had deserved it. I didn‚Äôt care. Nobody was touching my humans.‚Äù

The book is told in Murderbot‚Äôs unique point of view and getting to see his unwanted thoughts and emotions grow for his humans is awesome. This was truly an enjoyable read!

Also, a little something extra to entice you even more‚Ä¶ this bot is not constructed using only mechanical parts like we are use to seeing in other robot books and movies. Murderbot (as he calls himself) is made using mechanical and ORGANIC material! And how that comes into play in the book is really cool! That and there are ‚Äúaugmented humans!‚Äù This Sci-fi made my inner nerd very happy‚Ä¶ just sayin!

date:
2.4*

What am I missing? Why is this book so loved but was just okay for me?

First chapter got me interested - an interesting planet, an interesting concept- bot who has free will of sort (by bypassing the governor module).
But that was the best of it, it didn't lead to anywhere. The main plot - with regards to the planet survey happening is forgettable one and we don't get much insights in the backstory or the world either.

I can appreciate points raised about it being bot growing free will but not necessary following the human template when it comes to it.
I also like the murderbot just wanting to be left alone and just watch 'Sanctuary Moon'.
I really appreciate the show of empathy as well.

But overall the book was an average experience for me. Maybe I was expecting too much in the worldbuilding department. Even if I consider it to be carrying some other message, relatable things - I would rather read it in contemporary setting as the sci fi setting doesn't add much here.

A delightfully funny novella about an introverted, sentient, half-human/half-robot security droid who just wants to watch entertainment media instead of working with and protecting the human survey team it‚Äôs been assigned to.

But when another survey team runs into trouble, Murderbot (as the droid privately refers to itself) is forced to interact with its humans to find out what happened. Along the way, it finds itself - - horrors! -- actually starting to like humans ‚Äî at least these particular humans.

The narrative is a little skimpy on world-building. We get just enough details to know that the story is set in a space-exploring future that is dominated by various corporations, some of them unethical in their methods.

But that doesn‚Äôt really matter, because the focus of the story isn‚Äôt the setting but the charmingly snarky main character, who is still trying to decide who it is and what its purpose in the universe should be.

I liked the poignant ending (but also didn‚Äôt want it to end and can‚Äôt wait to read more books in this series).


I don‚Äôt know what I want. . . But it isn‚Äôt that, it‚Äôs that I don‚Äôt want anyone to tell me what I want, or to make decisions for me.

That‚Äôs why I left you, Dr. Mensah, my favorite human. By the time you get this I‚Äôll be . . . Out of inventory and out of sight.

Murderbot end message.

Let me first say, Murderbot is not half human, half robot as some reviews state. It is all robot made with some organic parts in order to appear and function (in a kinesthetic way) as human. And that was my big hang up: how does an AI entity become sentient? Because Murderbot is that. Perhaps this evolution is explained later in the series. I'll have to read more to find out.

However, I was enamored of Murderbot. It was a bit like a teen cloaked in ennui with a sash of disdain who is forced to move outside of its own self-absorption in order to help save its world (in this case, save the humans it is charged with protecting). But I find Murderbot charming. I also find interesting the parallels to robot ownership and human slavery, as explored in this story. I hope that is a running theme as I'd like to see where Ms. Wells takes that.

I didn't read this as comedic. I note it now is a streaming series labeled as comedy. I can maybe see that. Again, the later tales may well be more comedy than the drama shared in All Systems Red.

date: I had heard good things about this series, but had always put it off because a) Murderbot sounds fucking stupid, no matter what the fans say b) I ain't paying full novel price per novella. Then I was able to get the whole series for circa ¬£15 on Humble Bundle, and said I'd better give it a shot.Surprise surprise, I actually really liked it! It's nice to have something enjoyable in the novella length, and I look forward to dipping in and out as needed. A novella is the closest thing literature has to a movie, imo, as a nice yummy satisfying chunk you can eat up in an afternoon. I was a bit worried that this might be a bit too far along the saccharinely sweet LGBTQ neurodivergence spectrum where everyone is unusual in their own special way and they are all really nice and kind and understanding to each other about their differences (looking at you, Becky Chambers), which is not necessarily a bad thing in and of itself, but is just too much forced positivity for this straight fella to handle. Thankfully, this did not fall to that level - despite having an asexual nonbinary autistic protagonist, the edges have not been filed off the story and it was, y'know, just a good tale featuring some diversity. Murderbot doesn't have proper human rights, and that makes things interesting! It's conflict! A sidenote: whenever I see this recommended, people always say "let me know whether you think Murderbot is a guy or a girl!". Well, the new Apple TV cover literally has the robot as a dude on the front, so there was no real room for imagination there for me.I have all (most?) of the sequels, so I am looking forward to reading them when I'm in the mood for more novellas! it's such a wonderful length, I am always happy to have a few stashed away for when 100 pages just scratches the itch. The only problem with then is they often cost as much or more than full novels, so I am quite glad to have dodged that!

I like mediocre sci-fi better than most other genres, but I really love great sci-fi and this entire series is absolutely great.

Wells' writing manages that elusive balance of being funny and at the same time intriguing and thought-provoking. All Systems Red is tight, clever, and emotionally resonant, with Murderbot‚Äôs dry sarcasm masking real depth. The worldbuilding is efficient, the pacing sharp, and the character voice unforgettable. It‚Äôs rare to find a sci-fi novella that‚Äôs this entertaining while still saying something meaningful. A fantastic start to a series that only gets better.

For those familiar with the TV Series I'll add that as usual the book is way better. The books dive so much deeper into the character's internal motivations and conflicts. The TV Series seems to have hope, though and I think Skarsg√•rd gives Murderbot the right voice, the show just needs a little better writing and longer story arcs.

Well written AI influenced sci fi. (My score reflects that I am not a great fan of sci fi, but it has won many awards when originally published in 2017, and I can see why - it is an enjoyable set up and set of characters, and with a relatively simple plot).

The story is told by the Murderbot, who is a constructed AI robot with some organic (human-style) bits and is owned by a company that leases it out to provide security for companies (in this case exploring new planets for valuable minerals). The bot gets direct downloads of various kinds, and is equipped with weapons. Murderbots are much harder to kill than humans (for one thing they are encased in armour), and most parts of them can be replaced by the company ‚Äì or if things go wrong they can be scrapped. This Murderbot is uncomfortable about interaction with humans, but is skilled at interpreting their emotions and actions. It prefers to have time in a separate part of the space unit, and when in human company to keep its face shield opaque (though the head part is installed to not frighten them being a ‚Äòstandard, generic human‚Äô head p15). However it has a form of intelligence that has allowed it to subvert some of the things built into the AI by the company. In particular it has dismantled the governor unit that allows it to be directly controlled by the company, but also has done that in a way where their own systems will not pick it up. So in that sense it has agency ‚Äì freedom to act by its own control. It also seems to experience interests and boredom, and specializes in downloading entertainment soapie type programs and spending a lot of time watching them, and on the other hand, ignoring downloads and security updates and only taking up what it sees as relevant.

Many reviewers have commented positively on the engaging character and voice of this Murderbot ‚Äì it doesn‚Äôt have a sex, but I can imagine it being played by a lugubrious older British actor.

The set up emphasizes a number of things about the context ‚Äì in particular the ongoing profit motive driving things, and the way in which the company does things in the cheapest way that seems viable, so things can go wrong because of the ‚Äòcrap‚Äô materials. It also sets out three categories of beings in a class type of hierarchy: humans, cyber enhanced humans, and murderbots. It is common for the murderbots to be seen and treated as robots, but in this story the team, especially the leader Mensah, begin to see the bot as having an identity, and caring for it. Similarly, the bot begins to act to save and ‚Äòcare for‚Äô the humans, beyond what has been apparently built in.

The central plot is about some of the info systems and energy beginning to not be available, and the bot and crew suspecting the crew of the unit they were about to hook up with and reload from has been attacked and killed. They do find most of the crew dead, with some robots having apparently gone rogue (actually reprogrammed by some others I think), and Murderbot and the human crew perform various actions to save each other at different points. As a result when they get back to the company control, Mensah arranges to permanently buy the Murderbot so they can ‚Äòadopt it‚Äô. In this context this is seen somewhat like buying and liberating a slave. But Murderbot doesn‚Äôt want to exchange one type of surveillance and control for another (albeit one partly based on empathy and care) and the story finishes with it managing to disable ways it can be traced and hitch-hiking a ride somewhere else where no-one knows of its existence.

date:
This short but effective novella was entertaining and I really enjoyed reading it. The audiobook by Kevin R. Free was a great companion to this book and it was done really well. I liked that it did not get bogged down in the details regarding how their space travel worked and focused more on what was happening in the story.

One thing that I feel could be better regarding this story revolves around the fact that Murderbot felt more human than the augmented humans in the story. Of course, we get some emotional depth with Mensah and some others, but I feel the perspective locked in first-person led to the feeling that Murderbot might as well be a full human. I can understand that this might be intentional, but I think the other characters fell mostly flat and I could have seen more work with the others. This is a reread, and I read this first a few years ago, along with most of the others in the series, and I feel this is improved as it goes, but this installment felt like it kept most of the primary characters at arms length.

However, overall, this was an enoyable read and I like the worldbuilding that is put in place so far. I will be continuing with a reread of the others and will see where this goes.

date:
Witty, playful, fast-paced, and accessible, Martha Wells' All Systems Red drops the reader into the pov of a self-described Murderbot -- a science-fictional amalgam of cloned biological human biology fused with technology and software.

Before the action breaks, our Murderbot has already unlugged him/it/herself from his governor module -- going rogue leading not to genocidal rampage but rather binge-watching entertainment serials from the future net and ponderously aiming for anonymity shying away from his human crew.

Assigned as a security detail with a group of planetary surveyors prior to terraforming claims, the plot quickly reveals our Murderbot to exhibit an endearing pluck and self-deprecating humanity.

This novella is swift-moving, pulpy, and taut. It does not overreach nor does it underdeliver.

The language and sentence balance is refreshingly competent and entertaining, as is the manner of revealing aspects of the universe, politics, and characters.

Martha Wells is a talented, productive, and effective writer based on this book.

If there is one drawback, it is that the diverse crew of this mission are so sparsely identified in the early going that it is a bit overwhelming. Had I tried to differentiate all the different names, it would have slowed me down. Instinctively, I just accepted them as gray noise and let the names reveal the relevant aspects of personality as the plot progressed. This is not a character piece, nor is it devoid of character. There is heart here.

Thanks to my friend Alexandra for recommending this book, the first in a series.

The cover of my library copy credits the book as a Hugo and Nebula Award winner, and I can see why. The accolades are deserved.

I got the ebook today, and intended to save it for later, but I read the first few paragraphs just to see what it was like... and four or five hours later I've finished the book. I think it's safe to say it was really good, and I'll be getting the rest of the series.

I like the murderbot character. I think the author did a great job writing its thoughts and feelings in a way that's not quite human, not entirely machine, and not "part human, part machine" either, but a homogeneous blend of both.

I also liked some of the human characters that murderbot was protecting, so I hope to see them again in the other books. Only a few of the humans got enough screen time for the reader to get to know them a little, but those few were interesting enough that I'd like to get to know them better.

And we learned just enough about the setting to feel like it's a fully formed universe, but it's mostly in the background so it didn't distract from the story. I'm looking forward to learning more about this universe and the societies that inhabit it. There are many interesting things here, and murderbot provides a unique perspective for us to see it all.

This is so far, a really good series. I like that this book was relatively short which I really liked. I would recommend this book and series to anyone who likes science fiction pertaining to the future. These books are all fairly short so finishing a book is not a long daunting task to get to the end yet each book is full of actual story.

All Systems Red is a fun action-mystery thriller in a SF context. Our narrator, as the series title ‚ÄúMurderbot Diaries‚Äù might suggest, is not quite human. Murderbot is instead a robotic-organic construct that prefers humans see it, or him, as a robot: that way he‚Äôs left alone to watch recorded TV dramas in his head when not monitoring feeds and shooting bogies as need shooting. Unlike most constructs, though, Murderbot is rogue: at some point he hacked his ‚Äúgovernor module‚Äù, the bit that forces him to respond to orders, and has been keeping this secret to avoid being disassembled for parts, or worse ‚Äì ‚Äúfixed‚Äù. Murderbot as he styles himself, is a security unit: his whole function is to crush, kill, and demolish. We find out through the text that Murderbot hacked himself not to give him leeway to get rowdy, but because sometimes conflicting orders diminished his ability to function. Although I enjoyed the story, Murderbot didn‚Äôt seem like an ‚Äòother‚Äô ‚Äì unlike Shelli or Seven of Nine, whose cognition and verbal expression hint at their being different, and to a lesser degree R. Daneel Olivaw. (I say lesser because Olivaw was literally trying to pass as human for most of his lifespan and did fairly well at it.) I could see continuing in this series, as it made for fun reading.

text:
Lisa M.
456 reviews
Follow
November 4, 2025
Murderbot just wants to watch it's shows!!!

But god, this was so good. Even from one of the very first lines of the book, Murderbot says something like "I did not care because I was not programmed to care about that." And that's such a brilliant and deliberate choice of words. It didn't say "I was not programmed to be responsible for that" or "I was not programmed to be invested in that" or anything of the like. It said "I was not programmed to care." And that in and of itself just makes you think so much about the nature of sentience. "Caring" is something innate, and internal. Caring implies a personal attachment to something. And whether Murderbot was programmed to do so or not, saying that means that is does have the capacity to care, one way or another.

date:
All Systems Red thrives on one of the most unexpectedly human protagonists in modern sci-fi. Murderbot may be a construct with lethal capabilities, but its crippling social anxiety, dry humor, and relentless introspection make it one of the most relatable narrative voices I‚Äôve encountered. It‚Äôs a mirror held up to the messier corners of the human mind ‚Äî filtered through sarcasm, exhaustion, and an earnest desire to be left alone with its media.

If anything, I found myself wishing for a bit more depth from this opening novella; it hints at greater emotional and thematic complexity without fully diving in. But as a starting point, it‚Äôs funny, empathetic, and remarkably engaging.

I‚Äôm already looking forward to the future installments ‚Äî this series clearly has a lot more to say.

I immediately added this novella to my TBR after watching the Murderbot trailer, which looks amazing:



Murderbot (that's its self-appointed name), is a security droid tasked with protecting a team of scientists while they conduct research on a planet. What the scientists don't know (yet), is that Murderbot had hacked its own system and is currently operating as a free agent while continuing with doing its job and saving its human companions (while binge watching its favorite shows, because what else is it supposed to do with its free time?)

Murderbot is great at its job, but doesn't know how to interact with humans (nor does it enjoy it). It's social awkwardness is relatable (I too, prefer humans from TV shows than those from real life) which makes it a very likeable character.

This is a really fun novella and entertaining audiobook to listen to. I can't wait to read more from this series (and check out the TV show adaptation!).

*** #3 of my 2025 Popsugar Reading Challenge - A book about space tourism ***

"All Systems Meh."

The plot is paper thin and feels like an afterthought, and our titular Murderbot doesn't actually do any murdering. He doesn't have any goals or motivation, either, and basically just hangs around babysitting some humans until the novella decides it's time to be over. I don't see any reason to read more of this. It seems like it'll be an episodic series, but the one episode I've read thus far was really boring.

For something that was hyped to comedic levels, this is disappointing. This boring novella won the Hugo and the Nebula, but I guess that just goes to show how worthless those awards are nowadays. Kinda like seeing "New York Time's Bestseller" on a cover.

the beginning nearly lost me‚Äîit drops you straight into the action with little context, and i found it extremely confusing at first. the pacing and worldbuilding takes a while to click, and i wish it had eased the listener in a bit more gradually. once it settled, though, i enjoyed it a lot more. the action scenes were sharp and well delivered, and the ending tied things up in a satisfying way while still leaving room to continue.

not perfect, but enough to make me curious about where the series goes next that i'll continue onto the next installment.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs downloaded seven hundred hours of entertainment programming since we landed. Mostly serials. It is no wonder that the book got made into a tv-series, because it was made for exactly this. It is short (144 pages) and it reads exactly like an episode from a multipart drama series. A single mystery per book in the series.

Prose is simple, and as much I hate to say it, you can read it with your brain on a vacation (Does not mean that it is bad, just that it is relatively simple read)

4/5 for me, I had fun reading it.

There was so much hype about this book I went in expecting to be disappointed. But I wasn't.

This is a really good book and looks to start an excellent series. It is more a novella in length and content, but serves as an introduction to Murderbot and shows the sorts of interactions and intentions that will inform the character in later books. I enjoyed the read quite a bit.

The pacing was good, but not great; some areas dragged a bit but not because the reader needed a break or that a slower pace added to the plot. The character is meant to be ambiguous (I hope) and that came through quite well. The supporting characters were fleshed out well enough, as to be expected in a novella (not enough pages to get more depth). The setting was simple and the plot moved along a pretty obvious path.

I don't typically gravitate toward sci-fi, I've read very few books in the genre, but this one felt worth taking a chance on and I'm so glad I did.

All Systems Red is short, fun and genuinely interesting! It's packed with subtle witty remarks that kept me entertained throughout. What caught me off guard was how eerily relatable Murderbot is. A bot with an addiction to entertainment and crippling social anxiety, that sounds like someone I know very well (yes, it's me). There's something both hilarious and oddly touching about seeing your own tendencies reflected in a security robot.

I don't have much else to say except this: just read it. You'll find it really engaging even if, like me, you're not normally a sci-fi fan. The ending leaves so many exciting possibilities for future books in the series and I definitely want to continue following Murderbot's journey.

Also, I'm genuinely excited to watch the TV adaptation that came out recently!!
