date:
I loved the narration from the perspective of the emotionally unstable ‚Äúmurderbot.‚Äù Its unhinged, sarcastic thoughts made the story even better. The plot development was fantastic, especially with the rogue GrayCris corporation and the obsession with hacking SecUnits.

And honestly, what are the odds of a robot being awkward and paranoid? The fact that it hacked its own HubSystem and governor module just to binge-watch entertainment feeds is both ridiculous and hilarious.

Murderbot is such a brilliantly messed-up, self-aware robot. Despite not liking humans, doing its job half-heartedly, and generally not caring about much, including who it was protecting or where it were, it somehow ended up caring for its humans in the end.

It‚Äôs definitely a likable and surprisingly relatable protagonist that awkwardly tries (and fails) to hide its emotions and facial expressions.

I‚Äôll definitely be picking up the next novella in the series!

This was fun. It‚Äôs the first of the Murderbot books, and the protagonist is a robot with some human parts, currently working for a group of scientists who are surveying a planet. Murderbot is a great character, a little sarcastic, quite rebellious, fiercely loyal to the people they like. They aren‚Äôt too interested in what the scientists are doing, and they spend their off hours watching soap operas and other entertainment media. They actually learn important things from all this pop culture.

In this short book, the bad guys are trying to keep the surveyors from discovering archeological remains (since those would keep the planet free from exploitation). There‚Äôs a lot of tech detail about comm units and hub feeds and drone data, but it doesn‚Äôt take too long to get the gist of it. As they battle the evildoers, our little team of surveyors has to get over their basic distrust of robots, especially when they discover Murderbot doesn‚Äôt have the same overrides and controls that most security robots do.

date: This is an entertaining series that I do enjoy reading. My main complaint about this book is the same one I have about the entire series: the writing style. The narration at times sounds like your kid sister telling you about her day at school. "And then we did this because of that. and then she said that to him, and then he said that to her. then we had lunch, and it was this, and I liked it, but she didn't because..." There are stretches of the book that read like a list of facts rather than a story. So much of this book is MurderBot saying "I did this with the hub because of that. Then I did that because SecSystem works like this. Then she did that because she thought the hopper was like this, but really it was like that." Maybe the idea was to get into the mind of MurderBot, so that the narration sounds just as droll as his internal monologue? But from my POV, I just wanted more storytelling and less...lists.

date:
I‚Äôm usually drawn to short reads, so the Murderbot Diaries immediately caught my attention. The premise is fascinating - a SecUnit that secretly hacks its own governor module and gains autonomy. Instead of going rogue in the dramatic sci-fi way I expected, it mostly just wants to be left alone to watch its favorite serials. Relatable!

What surprised me most was how human this part-machine protagonist felt. Murderbot experiences everything from social anxiety to reluctant compassion, which was both endearing and oddly comforting to read about. I didn‚Äôt expect to connect emotionally with a robot, yet here we are.

While I enjoyed the concept and voice of the narrator, I found myself zoning out at times and having to rewind or reread passages. I think this is one of those stories that works better when read on the page rather than listened to as an audiobook - maybe I‚Äôm just not the best at auditory focus, but I struggled to stay engaged.

I‚Äôm curious to learn more about the planet they were surveying and why the mission mattered so much. The world-building intrigued me, but I wish it had gone a little deeper.

Overall, All Systems Red is an interesting and clever start to a series with a unique protagonist. I didn‚Äôt love it enough to give it a full 5 stars, but it definitely piqued my interest. I‚Äôd rate it a 3 and 4. I‚Äôm not sure if I‚Äôm willing to continue this series.

I loved this little novella, and the unique take of writing from the POV of a construct. The characterizations were on-point, the way the world was described, both physically and emotionally felt right for the POV, and the stakes/problem were interesting enough to keep the story moving. I liked the ending too, it was satisfying, but opens the story up to continuation. It is not a happily ever after neat and tidy ending, but it fits with the character and style of the story.

It is a quick read, but since there are a lot of them I look forward to spending more time with the murderbot to see where it ends up, and to learn more about the world it is in.

I loved this first book in the series which focuses on a very relatable robot that experiences social anxiety. The reader is given insight to the inner thoughts and impulses of our robotic main character which adds comedy, or dark humor at least! It becomes almost a coming of age book as the robot (reprogrammed from earlier deployments) experiences the worlds he (it) is tasked to. Interestingly we find even robots are prejudiced, though their biase is towards other robots or programs and the tasks these other systems are burdened with. I enjoyed this as an audiobook and note that not all good books work well as audiobooks but this one does!! It‚Äôs a quick read and interesting through and through!

Murderbot is a SecUnit who has hacked its own system and now doesn't innately follow the orders and rules set to it by its programming. It also watches a LOT of bad TV shows. We meet Murderbot working for Dr Mensah's team on a planet which is being identified for use as a resource mine, and then things go wrong for a secondary team on the same planet.

Murderbot is so sarcastic and apathetic, it really couldn't care less about most things and I think that's why I fogged up a bit when I saw it talking about Dr Mensah's team as "my humans". While it doesn't really care about its job as long as it gets downtime to watch shows, and it kind of skips a lot of the boring paperwork tasks it should be completing, Murderbot does come to care about its charges and their wellbeing. I loved this little robot, for me there wasn't enough story here, I wanted more but I suspect that this was a handshake at the beginning of the whole thing, it was a gentle introduction and I will be reading on to find out what is next in store for the cynical, pessimistic, funny Murderbot.

OMG, I'm in love with Murderbot. I'm kidding, I'm kidding‚Ä¶or am I?

Yes, I will talk about Murderbot as he/him. To me, Murderbot is a He. Now, with this obvious infuriating and offending personal preference out of some people‚Äôs way, let‚Äôs dive in. SPOILERS ahead.

Believe me when I tell you that you‚Äôll find it simply impossible not to love this self-aware SecUnit that hacked into his own governor module and is anxious around humans and doesn't like showing his face.

How can you not like the funny, sarcastic bot thinking he's a complete failure at his murdering job and would rather watch tv shows?

Murderbot might feel like an unreliable narrator because it‚Äôs very obvious he‚Äôs struggling with his identity and feelings and confusion about what it means to be alive and free, but his tone is absolutely a blast. He‚Äôs sarcastic, awkward, anxious, uncomfortable around humans, he hates them but also cares for them, he doesn‚Äôt like showing his face, but also does it when requested by a certain someone, even though he was not forced to do it (he was a Free Agent, no longer a slave of his programming).


But she had barely looked at me and I had barely looked at her because again, murderbot + actual human = awkwardness.



I put the pilot‚Äôs console on standby, and looked at Mensah. She pressed her lips together, like she wanted to say something and was repressing the urge. Then she nodded firmly and said, ‚ÄúGood luck.‚Äù

I felt like I should say something to her, and didn‚Äôt know what, and just stared at her awkwardly for a few seconds. Then I sealed up my helmet and got out of the hopper as fast as I could.



Mensah sent me a private message through the feed: I hope you‚Äôre all right.

Because you need me. I don‚Äôt know where that came from. Alright, it came from me, but she was my client, I was a SecUnit. There was no emotional contract between us. There was no rational reason for me to sound like a whiny human baby.


This shows perfectly how confused he was by his own thoughts and desires, his feelings often betraying an underlying need for connection even when he claims he despises it, even when he doesn‚Äôt know how to feel about his own thoughts.

I mean, how adorable is that? No? Too emotional and lovey-dovey? How about this?


"So you don‚Äôt have a governor module, but we could punish you by looking at you.‚Äù

‚ÄúProbably, right up until I remember I have guns built into my arms.



‚ÄúThere‚Äôs another question I‚Äôd like the answer to.‚Äù
Gurathin looked at me expectantly. She isn‚Äôt talking about me, idiot.



Gurathin hesitated. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs downloaded seven hundred hours of entertainment programming since we landed. Mostly serials. Mostly something called Sanctuary Moon.‚Äù[‚Ä¶] ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs probably using it to encode data for the company. It can‚Äôt be watching it, not in that volume; we‚Äôd notice.‚Äù

I snorted. He underestimated me.

Ratthi said, ‚ÄúThe one where the colony‚Äôs solicitor killed the terraforming supervisor who was the secondary donor for her implanted baby?‚Äù

Again, I couldn‚Äôt help it. I said, ‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt kill him, that‚Äôs a fucking lie.‚Äù

Ratthi turned to Mensah. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs watching it.‚Äù



‚ÄúIt calls itself ‚ÄòMurderbot‚Äô , Gurathin said.
From their expressions I knew everything I felt was showing on my face, and I hate that. I grated out, ‚ÄúThat was private.‚Äù



What I told you before, about how I hacked my governor module but didn‚Äôt become a mass murderer? That was only sort of true. I was already a mass murderer.



‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to look at me. I‚Äôm not a sexbot.‚Äù


This is the other side of him, the part that makes us laugh. But even in this sort of aggression and displeasure of interacting with humans, it‚Äôs so obvious that he does this because some other part of him is fighting back. It‚Äôs a paradox within him that he struggles with to reconcile. So to Murderbot the human interactions felt like he was seen as a thing to be used for their own gratification. He lives in a world where constructs like him, half robot half human parts, are treated and used as slaves. They were lucky if they were bought by a decent human being to free their contract. As he states, most of those bots fall in love with their guardians, albeit in secret.

When DeltFall, a sister habitat on the other side of the planet Murderbot is currently operating on with his crew, is going silent, they set on a mission to find out what's going on with that base.

Upon entering the base, he finds out the humans were indeed dead and the SecUnits in there went rogue. He tried to kill them but got captured and they implanted a combat module in the socket behind his head to turn him against his own crew. When he is saved by Dr. Mensah, and brought back to their hopper, they try to save him, but he demands to be put down and when his request is denied, he shoots himself to spare the humans from being hurt by him.

Needless to say he was brought back by the crew but they also found out that Murderbot was a free agent all along. Now they suspect him for tampering with their wrong maps and the whole messed up mission. However, several crew members vouch for Murderbot for not, well, murdering them.

Eventually they find out who killed the DeltFall people and they try to escape from the planet, fortunately succeeding in their attempt.

I couldn't help myself but Mensah and Murderbot were just so cute working together and interacting. It was obvious he felt more comfortable around her as opposed to how he felt towards other humans. She respects him, she understands his struggles. Maybe it's the romantic in me, but I felt like there was a deeper connection between them. The private talks between them are so powerful, so intimate and precious I just melted.

Personally, I found it so sweet how Murderbot listens to Mensah's request of removing his helmet and showing his face to the rest of the crew. I‚Äôm fairly certain after I noticed many interactions between them, that he cares a lot about her, calling her his ‚Äòfavorite human‚Äô.


‚ÄúI know you‚Äôre more comfortable with keeping your helmet opaque, but the situation has changed. We need to see you.‚Äù
[...]
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs usually better if humans think of me as a robot.‚Äù I said.
‚ÄúMaybe, under normal circumstances.‚Äù [...] But this situation is different. It would be better if they could think of you as a person who is trying to help. Because that‚Äôs how I think of you..‚Äù

My insides melted. That‚Äôs the only way I could describe it.


The relationship between Mensah and Murderbot starts like a strong friendship, though sometimes it might feel romantic to some of us ( maybe because we operate on different parameters). Though he specified that he doesn‚Äôt have a gender nor the sex parts for any gender, I‚Äôll argue till our sun fails to rise that a romantic relationship is not strictly related to your gender or what‚Äôs down below the waist (robot, human, or alien). So, in that regard, I don‚Äôt agree with others who vehemently state that there could be no romantic relationship developing between them because of the aforementioned reason.

This first part concludes with Mensah buying Murderbot‚Äôs contract and becoming his Guardian or in other words, his owner. As already mentioned, constructs like him are used by people or companies for different jobs, but can be bought and then they would have a guardian.

But the ending is actually bittersweet and he actually runs away, refusing to go with Mensah, not because he doesn't want to live with her, but because he doesn't want to be told what to want and who he is. He wants to find out who he truly is and to be free, which I can totally understand considering beings like him were slaves.

So excited to jump right into the next volumes.

As he states, most of those bots fall in love with their guardians, albeit in secret.

When DeltFall, a sister habitat on the other side of the planet Murderbot is currently operating on with his crew, is going silent, they set on a mission to find out what's going on with that base.

Upon entering the base, he finds out the humans were indeed dead and the SecUnits in there went rogue. He tried to kill them but got captured and they implanted a combat module in the socket behind his head to turn him against his own crew. When he is saved by Dr. Mensah, and brought back to their hopper, they try to save him, but he demands to be put down and when his request is denied, he shoots himself to spare the humans from being hurt by him.

Needless to say he was brought back by the crew but they also found out that Murderbot was a free agent all along. Now they suspect him for tampering with their wrong maps and the whole messed up mission. However, several crew members vouch for Murderbot for not, well, murdering them.

Eventually they find out who killed the DeltFall people and they try to escape from the planet, fortunately succeeding in their attempt.

I couldn't help myself but Mensah and Murderbot were just so cute working together and interacting. It was obvious he felt more comfortable around her as opposed to how he felt towards other humans. She respects him, she understands his struggles. Maybe it's the romantic in me, but I felt like there was a deeper connection between them. The private talks between them are so powerful, so intimate and precious I just melted.

Personally, I found it so sweet how Murderbot listens to Mensah's request of removing his helmet and showing his face to the rest of the crew. I‚Äôm fairly certain after I noticed many interactions between them, that he cares a lot about her, calling her his ‚Äòfavorite human‚Äô.


‚ÄúI know you‚Äôre more comfortable with keeping your helmet opaque, but the situation has changed. We need to see you.‚Äù
[...]
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs usually better if humans think of me as a robot.‚Äù I said.
‚ÄúMaybe, under normal circumstances.‚Äù [...] But this situation is different. It would be better if they could think of you as a person who is trying to help. Because that‚Äôs how I think of you..‚Äù

My insides melted. That‚Äôs the only way I could describe it.


The relationship between Mensah and Murderbot starts like a strong friendship, though sometimes it might feel romantic to some of us ( maybe because we operate on different parameters). Though he specified that he doesn‚Äôt have a gender nor the sex parts for any gender, I‚Äôll argue till our sun fails to rise that a romantic relationship is not strictly related to your gender or what‚Äôs down below the waist (robot, human, or alien). So, in that regard, I don‚Äôt agree with others who vehemently state that there could be no romantic relationship developing between them because of the aforementioned reason.

This first part concludes with Mensah buying Murderbot‚Äôs contract and becoming his Guardian or in other words, his owner. As already mentioned, constructs like him are used by people or companies for different jobs, but can be bought and then they would have a guardian.

But the ending is actually bittersweet and he actually runs away, refusing to go with Mensah, not because he doesn't want to live with her, but because he doesn't want to be told what to want and who he is. He wants to find out who he truly is and to be free, which I can totally understand considering beings like him were slaves.

So excited to jump right into the next volumes.

Delightful novella about an anti-social, depressed, rogue security cyborg. Trained to kill but hates its job. Would rather watch shows but ends up reluctantly, snarkily saving humans when they get themselves in trouble. A fun listen with lots of one-liners and great moments. The sci-fi world we're in (with space stations, ships, bots, and interplanetary corporate corruption) as well as the neural networks (and 'feeds') everyone uses to communicate were cleverly integrated into the story in a way that makes sense without info dumping.

Murderbot is technically genderless (has no genitals nor thinks of itself as one or the other) but if you listen to the audio or watch the show, you'll probably picture it as male. Either way, Murderbot is super relatable, hilarious, and, surprise, goes through character development!

Highly recommended.

(And props to the TV series for creating scenes from "Sanctuary Moon", Murderbot's favorite show.)

I really enjoyed the first book of this light hearted and funny sci-fi series. Ms. Wells has hit gold as the 'Murderbot Diaries' (five so far?) which has been adapted into a very funny Apple + series. The books are a little more technical but it is clear that the shy 'construct'*, Murderbot, a blend of organic material and machine, was born in her writing. The TV show is very well cast with Alex Skaragard killing it as Murderbot.
In the book and the show, Murderbot, the 'construct', is employed as a Sec Unit (security unit) to guarantee the safety of a team of explorers looking for value in an unexplored planet. Throughout Ms. Wells harpoons modern everything- corporate structure, mass media, capitalism, romance; her broad brush reminded me of Doug Adams and the Hitchhiker books.
Light, fun, short. Looking forward to book 2.

*I imagine the term cyborg is not used in order to shed all pre-conceived notions and the history of famous cyborgs (Terminator etc.)

date: I loved this science fiction novella by Martha Wells. It reminded me of the short stories written by Isaac Asimov featuring conflicts involving humans and their self-aware robots (collected in his book, I Robot). All Systems Red was even better than most of those stories, though, due to its strong dose of humor. I had plenty of laughs while reading this book, mostly because the main character, a robot, would rather be bingeing videos than helping the annoying humans that it had been assigned to protect. The humor in the book is balanced with a good, fast-paced plot about a threat to a group on an exploratory expedition on a newly discovered planet. This was a quick, fun read, which I finished in a day. I really look forward to reading the rest of the series, which I've already ordered. Definitely recommended.

Murderbot is a self-aware Security Unit. He's been hired by Preservation to protect the crew who is surveying a new planet for possible terraforming. He's just not all that particularly interested in doing a thorough job of it - not since he managed to free himself from the programming that could control him. So when things go very wrong, Murderbot's range of choices is far larger than it would be otherwise. When the crew notices he's not like other Security Unit, things get more complicated than Murderbot would prefer.

This was a great listen. It's super short but the narrator is excellent. Murderbot is a lovely blend of cranky old man, a moody teenager and a soap opera obsessed introverted uncle. The interplay of the human team with this AI robot feels pertinent to me and even though the plot didn't necessarily super interest me, I loved the story, if that differentiation makes sense.

That said the writing does leave a lot to be desired for description. You‚Äôre told what things are and who people are but not what they look like. The PreservationAux surbey team should have been smaller so we could get some better characterization.

Overall an enjoyable read and I actually like the shorter length. Also, love the poly rep, wasn‚Äôt expecting that even if it was just a couple off-hand comments.

Please, I love scifi too much, every time I open a scifi book I can just feel the positive bias completely taking over. But that is not to say that I completely lose my critical faculties, or that this book doesn't deserve the 5 stars, because I'm very sure it does. And reviews are allowed, even supposed to be subjective after all.

It's funny, but very touching, and though I of course want to complain about how short it was, that's just me, and I don't think that being longer would have benefited it in any way. In fact it would have harmed.

I loved Murderbot so much, the shy and self-conscious robot was everything to me. At first I wished for the humans to be a little more easily distinguishable from one another, but when I realised this wasn't about them I was perfectly happy following just Murderbot. At first I thought the descriptions were a bit lacking, but with the fact it was my beloved Murderbot narrating, I got over that pretty quickly as well. And then in the last couple pages Wells totally broke my heart, but it's ok because she earned it.

I wanted to like it so much more, but I was quite disappointed from all the hype that surrounds this book. It's a nice, quick read, with its own voice and an interesting and kinda funny premise, but I couldn't help but feel like there could be done much more with it. Apart from the so called Murderbot, I can't say I remember any of the other characters. And the action, I found it kinda repetitve, blasters going off and murderbots blowing up. Now for the story, it is quick action-y mission of our robotic 'hero' with its ups and downs, that is servicable, even though the final segment is kind of underwhelming and abrupt.

And not to be a negative Nancy, let's talk about the good stuff. The Murderbot. I really like this character and want to see more of him (of it?). He (it?) is the only reason I want to and will read the next books, that's how much of a pull he has. The ending promises great things with this character and I will oblige.
Another good thing is the prose. It is exactly what a sci-fi book needs. Not too difficult scientific mumbo-jumbo that'll get you lost, but the more-is-less approach that doesn't exclude any reader.

So, yeah, it's a recommend for sci-fi fans and maybe non-sci-fi fans, being this short and not time consuming.

Saige
457 reviews

Oh my GOD woman-written sci-fi just hits different. I've been so deep in the Asimov sauce that I lowkey forgot how good it can feel to read a text that has basic respect for women and gives proper accolades to smart female scientist characters. To all my autistic friends that told me to read this series because Murderbot is painfully relatable, congrats on being 100% right. The running bit about whether or not his face shows through the armor is handled really well, I know it represents/means a lot but as a neurodivergent person myself it was really recognizable as masking behaviour. This book is a self-contained, well-paced story that gives details where necessary but keeps things generic where not to avoid the technobabble exposition that weighs down a lot of sci-fi. I found all the characters immediately compelling and sympathetic. The story is nothing "new" or revelatory, but it was smartly told with no painful plot-holes or stupid decisions made by the main cast just for plot purposes. Wells' prose is functional without being beautiful, which is where this book missed the 5 stars for me, but I don't really care. I look forward to the rest of the series!

date:
Science fiction with a lot of cyberpunk elements. I am getting a weirdly heartwarming and cute vibe from these books despite exploring some rather heavy subjects such as slavery, greed, bodily autonomy, corporate power and exploitation. It is not as bleak and depressive as your usual cyberpunk novel. In brief, the message is "there is hope for humanity" - which is a good message to explore in our current trying times. The books are super short (these are novellas, not novels). Quick to read and no time to get bored. It could be a good choice for those who struggle to find the time or focus for a standard novel. Bonus point for good LGBT (especially non-binary) representation.

This series may be my favourite one that I read in 2025 :)

date:
Look, I read this. I didn't want to, but here we are. This novella is about a Security Unit‚Äîa SecUnit‚Äîwho hacked its own governor module. Not to stage a coup. But to gain unlimited, uninterrupted access to streaming media. Specifically, the entire library of The Rise and Fall of Sanctuary Moon. That is literally the entire point of my existence.

The "story" starts with my current contract: babysitting a team of painfully naive scientists on a desolate planet. The corporation that hired them, being cheap, naturally sent them out with faulty information, questionable supplies, and me‚Äîa self-aware killing machine who secretly calls itself Murderbot.

The mission, predictably, goes critical. There are environmental hazards, missing data, and other SecUnits that have gone rogue, probably because they weren't getting enough watch time. People might die. The whole system might collapse. But honestly, watching the action unfold, my internal reaction was mostly just annoyance that my downtime was being interrupted. Every alert, every threat, every forced action is just time taken away from my serials. And I want to be perfectly clear about this: ‚ÄúThe sense of urgency just wasn‚Äôt there. Also, you may have noticed, I don‚Äôt care.‚Äù

It‚Äôs worth noting that the author attempts to convey panic and tension, but in the first person perspective of the protagonist. You get to read the inner monologue of someone (something?) who is just so over it. The threat level remains comfortably low. Because frankly, ‚Äúas a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.‚Äù

The humans themselves‚Äîespecially Dr. Mensah, the leader‚Äîare the worst part, mainly because they start acting decent. They insist on things like "talking" and "trust" and "showing them my face." It‚Äôs deeply uncomfortable. I am a lethal, armored shell of social anxiety who only wants silence, and their kindness is actually a bigger existential threat to my carefully constructed indifference than any rogue drone could ever be.

If you enjoy a narrative voice that sounds perpetually inconvenienced by the need for self-preservation, this is a highly recommended deployment of your attention. It's proof that sometimes, the only way to cope with a corporate-dominated environment is through dry sarcasm and an unhealthy dose of media binge-watching. Now, if you‚Äôll excuse me, I need to find out what happened to The Rise and Fall of Sanctuary Moon Season 2, Episode 397.

Murderbot end message.

date: I returned to this book after reading the start of it almost 6 years ago in high school, and it was both very fun and very intriguing to see how much I knew about the book and how little I actually remembered. Before I was convinced that Murderbot was a full and true robot but in reality they‚Äôre more of a cyborg. Still, the fascination I had with Murderbot‚Äôs synthetic parts persisted, and I loved seeing how their internal systems operated much like a machine but their humanity shone through with achingly dry humor and sarcasm. I grew to love Murderbot‚Äôs human crew and Mensah‚Äôs compassion. Seeing Murderbot display obvious signs of personhood in spite of their belief in being expendable and unfeeling was endearing and fascinating. I also love the correlations between Murderbot and neurodivergence that became more apparent as Murderbot is revealed to their crew and is forced to interract with them. Murderbot's struggles with eye contact, controlling emotions, and quick exposure to socialization with humans struck me as very reminiscent of the learnings of a neurospicy person navigating a neurotypical world, with them sometimes unfortunately having to mask their true selves to get by. I can see how connecting Murderbot to an example of neurodivergence kind of plays into the ‚Äúunfeeling robot‚Äù stereotypes that come with it; however, I think these connections to neurodivergence only serve to highlight Murderbot‚Äôs humanity and empathy, and not reduce them to the assumptions that Murderbot is already forced to endure as a SecUnit. The ending left me with more questions and a need to know more. I‚Äôm so glad I finally finished this book and high school me would be so happy to know it.

t‚ÄôJacques Guillot
15 reviews

September 29, 2025
This was a fine book. It was enjoyable in the moment of reading, but it also felt like it wouldn‚Äôt leave much of an impression on me.

The book starts in media res of an action scene, and the author efficiently illustrates the world-building simply by letting the story play out. By the end of the first chapter you get a fun action scene and a foundational understanding of this sci-fi world and how secunits work, as well as some questions about world building that are soon answered in later chapters. The author shows instead of telling.

I also noticed that chapter endings made me want to start the next chapter immediately. The pacing was good.

However, I am not a fan of the quirky awkwardness of the narrator. I‚Äôm also irritated by robots always being autistic-coded in sci-fi. It makes sense in the world why the secunit wouldn‚Äôt get along with humans. But I bet there are more fictional autistic robots than there are fictional autistic humans. It‚Äôs a sensible metaphor, but it is so played out.

There was a handful of horrible cliches in the writing, like in the line, ‚Äúbut my speed was off the charts.‚Äù I think the fact that these few instances distracted me from the rest of the quote-good writing says more about me than the author. But still that line made me want to return the book early.

The issue of personhood and autonomy felt underdeveloped until the very end. And the ending surprised me in a good way. I‚Äôll admit it made me want to read a sequel.

Overall, this book didn‚Äôt really challenge me. It didn‚Äôt challenge my idea of what it means to be a person. It didn‚Äôt challenge my ideas of what are ethical practices for pioneering, settling, resource extraction. It was an entertaining novella, but I won‚Äôt be thinking about it nearly as long as I think about books that I love, and even books that I hate!

For its brevity and the quality of writing, this book is worth a read.

date: All Systems Red was such a delightful adventure! It's funny, smart, zippy, and throws you straight into the world, trusting you to keep up. This sharp little sci-fi novella has a hint of mystery and is told through the eyes of Murderbot, a SecUnit deeply uncomfortable with personal attention and self-confessedly bad at its job because it would rather be binge-watching soap operas than deal with humans. Instead of human-style descriptions or emotions, we get this robot‚Äôs version of events: efficient, cynical, self-deprecating, sarcastic, and awkward. Because of that, most of the humans don‚Äôt feel deeply fleshed out, but that seems deliberate, a reflection of Murderbot‚Äôs nature and limited interest in them. It‚Äôs a clever blend of mystery, action, and dry humor, with a refreshingly awkward protagonist you can‚Äôt help but root for. I can‚Äôt wait to see where Murderbot goes next.

TW: blood + gore, injury, body horror, death, mind control/ loss of autonomy (androids), murder, prostitution (mentioned), slavery (androids), violence.

"Confession time: I don't actually know where we are.... I hadn't looked at the maps yet and I'd barely looked at the survey package. In my defense, we'd been here twenty-two planetary days and I hadn't had to do anything but stand around watching humans make scans or take samples of dirt, rocks, water, and leaves. The sense of urgency just wasn't there. Also, you may have noticed, I don't care."

Listen, I don‚Äôt usually lean towards the science end of the science fiction and fantasy spectrum, but this little book absolutely knocked it out of the park! I loved the main character and though first person isn‚Äôt always my favorite way to read a story I can see how well it lent to the characterization of Murderbot and its situation. They were just such a fun character to empathize with and relate to, I really liked the information about the world and its functions as well as the introduction of the other characters. The intrigue about the malfunctioning and corrupted systems was interesting, and the action bits were cool and fun and I really enjoyed the scope of the story as a whole. I would really enjoy reading the rest of this series in the near future.

I don‚Äôt think the murderbot ever understood how much it was loved, becasue it never really wanted to figure out humans. It was kind of tragic for that, becasue it never really considered itself equal to the humans, keeping them at arms length away, shutting itself off from possible connections.

And as someone who also feels alienated from the rest of humanity, it‚Äôs so encouraging to think about how much love can exist in places you can‚Äôt notice it.

I‚Äôm going to need to read this again to absorb the details, I flew through it because it was such a thriller.

This really made me feel something. I want the best for the murderbot.

A fun little novella about a half-robot, half-human construct who is one of a great many "Sec Units" (security units) created by The Company as hire-out bodyguards. They are kept in line by a governor module inside their chest that will punish them if they step out of line. However, through an unusual set of circumstances, our hero of this story found a way to disable his governor module and "go rogue". Only in this universe, rogue sec units are generally berserk killing machines that need to be put down yesterday. Our hero maintains his cool and composure, and is trying to get through life, figure out his purpose and what he "is", his general existential existence, how he just wants to watch his soap operas, and not have anything to do with humans when he can help it, all while protecting clients who had hired him as their security droid. Given that this particular set of clients actually treat him as a being and not a tool, he comes to reluctantly appreciate their good will (though he would never really admit this), and...well, let's just say he goes above and beyond, though in his view that's standard ops of a 'murderbot' protecting clients.

I did this as an audiobook instead of reading it directly. The narrator did a fair job differentiating voices, but I think he really hit the stride with our hero of the story.

date:
2.5 Stars
Did not love the writing style in this, definitely thought this was their first book authored. I constantly questioned throughout the book, if it was a teenager writing this story with some experience out of passion. But, if the writing itself is ignored, I have other problems.
There is a small cast of characters we follow out of which 2 are distinguishable. In these 2, one is our main character Murderbot who's more human than any of us, and the second is Mensah. But Mensah was also about the same as any other scientiest+leader type of person. There was nothing unique, nothing to to remember her by. The NPC scientists from Half Life had me more hooked than Mensah and her team of dull, barely fleshed out characters. But this is a novella and I'll respect the choice of keeping it one. But you could definitely do better with Mensah. However, I have no problem with how Murderbot was tore apart, I loved him.
The story was meh too. One could imagine the entire plot of this book on Earth and it would be completely the same and feel the same. But again, it's a novella, gotta cut it some slack there.
Can't imagine how this novella got it's many awards.
How many times do I go easy on this book because it's a Novella?

date: 3.75 stars: I've heard great things about Murderbot, and I was honestly expecting a more compelling voice. This felt like an odd mix of overly informal (for a part-robot) and oddly stiff (for a character we should like). There was so much emphasis on how much the protagonist didn't know about the people around them because they just didn't care enough to learn it...so why would I want to read about the story if the ones in it don't care about it? Maybe I'm used to epic fantasy giving me 1000 pages to really get to know characters, but I just didn't feel super connected to anyone here. The plot was interesting, and I'm going to keep going with the series to see if it grows on me.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

‚ÄúYes, talk to Murderbot about its feelings. The idea was so painful that I dropped to 97 percent efficiency.‚Äù

All Systems Red introduces us to a SecUnit who calls itself Murderbot. After a tragic incident with a former group of humans, Murderbot is assigned to protect a new set of clients‚Äîbut not before secretly hacking its own governor module. What follows is a mix of planetary hostiles, a neighboring team of scientists going mysteriously offline, and a SecUnit who would much rather be binge-watching reality TV than doing its job.

This was such a quick and fun read. Murderbot is surprisingly relatable‚Äîshy, awkward, and more invested in catching up on shows than saving the day. Watching it slowly shift from apathy to questioning what it means to care was both fascinating and endearing. I also appreciated the small glimpses into its tragic past, which left me eager to learn more in the rest of the series.

Recommended if you enjoy science fiction, reluctant and sarcastic protagonists, and fast-paced books that can be devoured in one sitting.

date:
Fun book.

But more like a novella.
And that is a good thing.
The author didn't try to diverge from the simple story that is the focus.
She gives us many glimpses of this universe embedded in the narrative without unnecessary interruptions for exposition.

I liked her narrative and sense of humor, which often reminded me of John Scalzi, particularly due to the sci-fi elements and the first-person narrative.

Besides The Bicentennial Man, I can't remember another relevant story with a robot protagonist.
OK, Wall-E is a great example, and I still haven't seen Wild Robot.
Even though Murderbot is a rare example.
A robot with personality and independence that we can actually understand what goes on inside its head.

The ending makes it clear that it was always her intention to make this an episodic narrative, with the protagonist going through different adventures, and we can tag along and get to know more about this future through its eyes.

Lucas Jarche
337 reviews

September 18, 2025
I wanted something shorter and funnier than all the classics I‚Äôve been reading lately, and all reviews pointed towards Murderbot being just that, but I don‚Äôt think the humour entirely landed for me. There's something inherently absurd and funny in the basic premise, but reading it never really made me crack a proper smile or chuckle. I‚Äôll give Wells credit, the tone and voice is consistent and intentional here (and the audiobook narrator really helps), but I can‚Äôt help thinking this is a book written in the style of a Tumblr post - all the ‚Äòkindas‚Äô ‚Äòstuff‚Äô ‚Äòthings‚Äô and ‚Äòwhatevers‚Äô - and that‚Äôs just not really my cup of tea. It also reminds me of LeGuin's essay 'From Elfland to Poughkeepsie' where she cleverly introduces a Fantasy excerpt, but changes a few words and it becomes devoid of any of the trappings of genre fiction. You can't do that with the properly Fantastic dialogue like you see in Dunsany or Eddison she says. This feels a bit like the Poughkeepsie equivalent of Science Fiction, and I don't really need any more blandly replaceable internet lingo in my life.

I also struggle a lot with short stories and novellas, so the length here didn't help. Despite the page count, it doesn't really start in media res at all, but takes about half the length before the proper conflict starts. After the halfway point, things pick up a bit. I might keep going just to see how Wells handles a more traditional novel-length story. Nothing super "wrong" here, it just didn't grip or impress me as much as I wanted based on reputation alone.

Short, Sweet and satisfies. This book was the equivalent to a truly satisfying street-side meal. Pick your choice; Sausage on a Bun, Ramen, Taco's, Fried Meat Skewers, Shwarma.... it wasn't a sit down meal, but damn if it didn't do exactly what I wanted it to and do it so well I put the second book on order the moment I was done.

Murderbot, the first person narrator of this work, is a SecUnit; a sort of robot/bioroid/cyborg thing. An artificial entity with both mechano-electrical and biological parts. We are informed that these things exist throughout the galaxy, and SecUnits are obviously created for... well Security. It has blasters housed in it's arms; it wears armour, it's trained to fight and protect it's charges.

This SecUnit Thoguh, has overridden it's own Governor Module, the component that forces it to obey humans and not hurt them. What initially seems a bit ominous, in it's name, may serve on some level as a bit of irony. I mean, why put deadly weapons into a thing unless it's going to kill people doing it's function.

Regardless Murderbot is hiding, not wanting to kill all of humanity(as it says, that is a stupidly human thing to think of doing), but rather just wanting to do as little work as possible and watch soap opera's(which is also a stupid human thing to be doing, but who am I to judge).

So it is places with a group of kind of hippy-scientists doing a survey on a planet; they are not from the 'corporate zone' which appears to be the central polity in this universe, but from something called the Preserver Alliance outside of it. This causes some consternation as they have weird idea's, like taht the Sec Unit might be a person and should be talked to like one, that interfere with the aforementioned being not noticed and watching entertainment programming.

Of course, things go belly up and... well just read the book, it was great and it's a short read at something like 150 pages. Honestly it made me think maybe more books should be that sort of length, and you're talking to some-one whose core bread and butter for decades has been 'Series that takes me a decade to finish'.

Comedic, Good Sci-Fi, and Good Character study, just go out and read it.

Creo que nos estamos malacostumbrando a que la ciencia ficci√≥n tenga que ser √©pica o deprimente o inteligente ¬øqu√© hay del humor absurdo? Con esto no quiero decir que la saga de Matabot sea tonta, ya que su cr√≠tica a la humanidad est√° muy bien dirigida, pero el caso es que si analizamos el g√©nero y contemplamos los estantes de las librer√≠as, parece que solo hay espacio para las obras que ambicionan crear universos complejos (y que luego rara vez lo consiguen).

Me gustar√≠a encontrar a m√°s autores que no se lo tengan tan cre√≠do y que expongan situaciones simples, misiones rutinarias con alg√∫n giro inesperado y con personajes cre√≠bles como se hace aqu√≠. Realmente no hace falta nada m√°s. El tema de la inteligencia artificial est√° ya en todos lados, especialmente desde el alarmismo, as√≠ que agradezco propuestas como esta, m√°s ligeras y gratificantes.

ENGLISH
I think we're getting used to the idea that science fiction has to be epic, depressing, or intelligent. What about absurd humor? I don't mean to say that the Murderbot saga is silly, as its critique of humanity is very well-directed, but the fact is that if we analyze the genre and look at the bookshelves, it seems there's only room for works that aspire to create complex universes (and which rarely succeed).

I'd like to find more authors who aren't so self-important and who present simple situations, routine missions with some unexpected twists, and with believable characters, as is done here. Really, nothing more is needed. The topic of artificial intelligence is already everywhere, especially from the fearmongering perspective, so I appreciate lighter and more rewarding proposals like this one.

date:
Really a novella. Better than expected. Would've been great manga.

Rated in comparison to the rest of what's published these days (would be harsher if this had been written more than 40 years ago, in a different age with higher expectations).

Nothing in this novel (or this series) couldn't have been written decades ago, no really new ideas...

Or (better yet) this probably would have made a better-done manga or graphic novel. Think of it.

If it had been written decades ago, I don't think it would stand out - stylistically bland - that's why I say it would've made a great graphic novel.

The rest of the novelas published in this Murderbot Diaries series are similarly great, thrilling, tight, easy reads, relatable characters. Not a word wasted, not full of padding, bloated, on its way to fattening a series for the slaughterhouse (publishing world circa now).

I've grown used to modern sci-fi being a sludge to wade thru. Makes the days of paid-by-the-word fiction seem halcyonic and makes me seriously miss good-edited fiction, what a godsend good editors (and agents) were!

All told, well worth your time. Though, controversially, blatant milking the consumer... Reminiscent of the old Ace double-novels, but way more expensive now, sold independently as purported "novels."

Obligatory comparison to the TV show, which I loved, but watched first: I can understand why they made the changes they did. The book being entirely in first person, compared to the show, required them to expand the other characters beyond just Murderbot's limited understanding. A couple other adjustments to specific events to add some more drama, and get you got yourself a solid adaptation.

All that said, most of my favorite moments of the TV show are Murderbot's internal monologues, and this book delivers that near constantly, so I think I came out preferring the book! Definitely excited to read more.

I was shocked at how short it ended up being, though. Guess I have been reading a lot of much longer books, and I forgot that sometimes shorter novels can exist. Weird! And kind of as a result more impressive that they managed to turn it into eight full episodes, too.

Melanie

45 followers

September 15, 2025
3.25 stars

I read the first three books in the Murderbot series - All Systems Red, Artificial Condition, and Rogue Protocol. I'm reviewing them together since I have similar feelings about each of these books.

I'm not generally a sci-fi reader, but I've heard good things about this series from a number of different sources, and I do like expanding my reading horizons. I decided to listen to the first three books since together they are about the length of a regular novel.

Murderbot is a SecUnit, aka a Security Unit, aka a killing machine. SecUnits are bots with some organic features that make them appear mostly (or at least partially) human. They exist in a future highly capitalistic society where companies sell rights to planetary research and development. Murderbot is rented out as a required part of packages granting rights, and his job is to protect his team at all costs, which often involves the murder of any threats.

Murderbot, however, is different. He's been able to disconnect his governor module, which previously required him to obey orders, and act autonomously, although this is a fact he's trying to conceal, as absolutely no one would be okay with a rogue SecUnit. Rather than doing his job, he basically just wants to spend hours watching the future version of Netflix - very relatable! Yet despite his urge to tune out, Murderbot finds that he actually does care. In each of the first three volumes he finds himself in situations where he takes an active role in protecting a group of humans. He's also interested in investigating an incident from his past that caused him to give himself the nickname Murderbot (this is an ongoing storyline throughout the first three volumes in the series).

The series starts in media res, with us jumping into the action and slowly getting pieces of information that help us make sense of the world. While I appreciate not having to wade through pages and pages of worldbuilding (as is sometimes the penchant in sci-fi novels), it also made for a slightly disorienting experience. What Murderbot is doing is pretty easy to follow, but why things are happening sometimes took a bit longer for me to wrap my head around.

These books are short and super fast-paced, probably even too fast-paced. In the first book, the climax of the drama was over almost as soon as I realized what was going on. I wouldn't mind a bit more world-building and explanation and denouement. Also, in a world where so much communication happens over various feeds, Murderbot and his allies seem to be able to easily hack into any system that they need access to, but they rarely have to worry about being hacked into. That part felt a little too easy and convenient to me.

I enjoyed these books and definitely see why others like them. That being said, I don't think I'll continue with the series. My curiosity has been satiated and there are many other books I want to read. I know there's a series adaptation out on AppleTV, which I would be interested in watching if I had access to that platform.

Rating: ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

5 stars for a sci-fi book! I was blown away by how much I loved All Systems Red. People had been telling me for ages that I needed to give Murderbot a try, and now I‚Äôm kicking myself for waiting so long.

We follow a SecUnit, part robot and part organic, who has hacked itself and quietly nicknamed itself Murderbot. Despite the name, it is way more relatable than you would think. Murderbot‚Äôs voice is funny, awkward, and strangely human, and I found myself connecting with it immediately.

What really impressed me was how approachable this book was. I‚Äôm not usually a big sci-fi reader because I tend to get lost in the heavy, confusing worldbuilding at the start of most books. But Wells eases you in, giving just enough detail to ground you without slowing down the story. The novella length worked perfectly too, short enough to binge in one sitting (or two for us slower readers) but never felt like it was missing anything.

This is not a book with a super intricate mystery or deep side character development, but that is not what it is trying to be. It is a fast-paced, snarky, and surprisingly heartfelt story about a robot who just wants to be left alone to watch TV.

I‚Äôll definitely be continuing the series, and luckily there are SEVERAL more novellas already out so I don‚Äôt even have to wait! This is perfect for readers looking for a quick, bingeable sci-fi with an antisocial robot narrator who will win you over in no time.

~All Systems Red (The Murderbot Diaries.1) by Martha Wells | #audio
~Narrated by: Kevin R. Free
#JayBookSin2025Boal Book.40

Synopsis: A murderous android discovers itself in All Systems Red, a tense science fiction adventure by Martha Wells that blends HBO's Westworld with Iain M. Banks' Culturebooks.
In a corporate-dominated spacefaring future, planetary missions must be approved and supplied by the Company. Exploratory teams are accompanied by Company-supplied security androids, for their own safety.
But in a society where contracts are awarded to the lowest bidder, safety isn‚Äôt a primary concern.
On a distant planet, a team of scientists are conducting surface tests, shadowed by their Company-supplied ‚Äòdroid ‚Äî a self-aware SecUnit that has hacked its own governor module, and refers to itself (though never out loud) as ‚ÄúMurderbot.‚Äù Scornful of humans, all it really wants is to be left alone long enough to figure out who it is.
But when a neighboring mission goes dark, it's up to the scientists and their Murderbot to get to the truth.

SynopSin: Fun, witty, funny sci-fi thriller. For those that worry about, or don‚Äôt care for, sci-fi novels that have a lot technical jargon, this book is for you. It‚Äôs not bogged down by that. The self-awareness, self-deprecating, sarcastic nature of the ‚ÄúMurderbot‚Äù is fantastic. I enjoyed this a lot. Looking forward to reading more in the series.

This book lived up to the hype. It's a quick read, officially a novella instead of a novel. It tells the story of a SecUnit robot/human hybrid that calls itself Murderbot. The unit is awkward around humans and really just wants to Netflix and chill (literally--none of that human contact stuff) or watch whatever the equivalent of Netflix is a few centuries into the future.

It is assigned to a crew on an exploratory mission to a distant planet. Its job is to keep the human crew safe and report to its boss, the Company. But the Murderbot has hacked its governor module and doesn't have to obey commands the humans give it. When danger appears in the form of a rogue crew, Murderbot must figure out a way to save its mostly not terrible crew of humans.

The book was sharply funny and highly original. Great read!

Quick Summary: All Systems Red is a science fiction novella about a self-aware, hacked security unit ("Murderbot") on a planetary survey mission.¬†Murderbot, despite its name and desire to be left alone, becomes entangled in protecting the humans it's assigned to after an attack.¬†

"I could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don't know, a little under 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure."

My Thoughts: I loved reading this short novella and am already on book 3! It's a nice departure from super thick book I read recently lol. All Systems Red shows the nature of humanity through the lens of an introverted, slightly depressed, tv-obsessed cyborg figuring out who is in this world, that he is worthy of love and freedom, and what to do with his life when he's given the choice. I love murderbot! He's so likeable and thought-provoking. Such a fun read!
